In sooth ||comma|| I know not why I am so sad:
It wearies me ||semicolon|| you say it wearies you ||semicolon|| 
But how I caught it ||comma|| found it ||comma|| or came by it ||comma|| 
What stuff ||single_quote|| tis made of ||comma|| whereof it is born ||comma|| 
I am to learn ||semicolon|| 
And such a want-wit sadness makes of me ||comma|| 
That I have much ado to know myself ||period|| 
Your mind is tossing on the ocean ||semicolon|| 
There ||comma|| where your argosies with portly sail ||comma|| 
Like signiors and rich burghers on the flood ||comma|| 
Or ||comma|| as it were ||comma|| the pageants of the sea ||comma|| 
Do overpeer the petty traffickers ||comma|| 
That curtsy to them ||comma|| do them reverence ||comma|| 
As they fly by them with their woven wings ||period|| 
Believe me ||comma|| sir ||comma|| had I such venture forth ||comma|| 
The better part of my affections would
Be with my hopes abroad ||period|| I should be still
Plucking the grass ||comma|| to know where sits the wind ||comma|| 
Peering in maps for ports and piers and roads ||semicolon|| 
And every object that might make me fear
Misfortune to my ventures ||comma|| out of doubt
Would make me sad ||period|| 
My wind cooling my broth
Would blow me to an ague ||comma|| when I thought
What harm a wind too great at sea might do ||period|| 
I should not see the sandy hour-glass run ||comma|| 
But I should think of shallows and of flats ||comma|| 
And see my wealthy Andrew dock ||single_quote|| d in sand ||comma|| 
Vailing her high-top lower than her ribs
To kiss her burial ||period|| Should I go to church
And see the holy edifice of stone ||comma|| 
And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks ||comma|| 
Which touching but my gentle vessel ||single_quote|| s side ||comma|| 
Would scatter all her spices on the stream ||comma|| 
Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks ||comma|| 
And ||comma|| in a word ||comma|| but even now worth this ||comma|| 
And now worth nothing ||question_mark|| Shall I have the thought
To think on this ||comma|| and shall I lack the thought
That such a thing bechanced would make me sad ||question_mark|| 
But tell not me ||semicolon|| I know ||comma|| Antonio
Is sad to think upon his merchandise ||period||

My ventures are not in one bottom trusted ||comma|| 
Nor to one place ||semicolon|| nor is my whole estate
Upon the fortune of this present year:
Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad ||period||

competency lives longer ||period||

ALL
Ding ||comma|| dong ||comma|| bell ||period|| 
So may the outward shows be least themselves:
The world is still deceived with ornament ||period|| 
In law ||comma|| what plea so tainted and corrupt ||comma|| 
But ||comma|| being seasoned with a gracious voice ||comma|| 
Obscures the show of evil ||question_mark|| In religion ||comma|| 
What damned error ||comma|| but some sober brow
Will bless it and approve it with a text ||comma|| 
Hiding the grossness with fair ornament ||question_mark|| 
There is no vice so simple but assumes
Some mark of virtue on his outward parts:
How many cowards ||comma|| whose hearts are all as false
As stairs of sand ||comma|| wear yet upon their chins
The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars ||semicolon|| 
Who ||comma|| inward search ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| have livers white as milk ||semicolon|| 
And these assume but valour ||single_quote|| s excrement
To render them redoubted ||exclamation_mark|| Look on beauty ||comma|| 
And you shall see ||single_quote|| tis purchased by the weight ||semicolon|| 
Which therein works a miracle in nature ||comma|| 
Making them lightest that wear most of it:
So are those crisped snaky golden locks
Which make such wanton gambols with the wind ||comma|| 
Upon supposed fairness ||comma|| often known
To be the dowry of a second head ||comma|| 
The skull that bred them in the sepulchre ||period|| 
Thus ornament is but the guiled shore
To a most dangerous sea ||semicolon|| the beauteous scarf
Veiling an Indian beauty ||semicolon|| in a word ||comma|| 
The seeming truth which cunning times put on
To entrap the wisest ||period|| Therefore ||comma|| thou gaudy gold ||comma|| 
Hard food for Midas ||comma|| I will none of thee ||semicolon|| 
Nor none of thee ||comma|| thou pale and common drudge

Which rather threatenest than dost promise aught ||comma|| 
Thy paleness moves me more than eloquence ||semicolon|| 
And here choose I ||semicolon|| joy be the consequence ||exclamation_mark|| 
[Aside] How all the other passions fleet to air ||comma|| 
As doubtful thoughts ||comma|| and rash-embraced despair ||comma|| 
And shuddering fear ||comma|| and green-eyed jealousy ||exclamation_mark|| O love ||comma|| 
Be moderate ||semicolon|| allay thy ecstasy ||comma|| 
In measure rein thy joy ||semicolon|| scant this excess ||period|| 
I feel too much thy blessing: make it less ||comma|| 
For fear I surfeit ||period||

A gentle scroll ||period|| Fair lady ||comma|| by your leave ||semicolon|| 
I come by note ||comma|| to give and to receive ||period|| 
Like one of two contending in a prize ||comma|| 
That thinks he hath done well in people ||single_quote|| s eyes ||comma|| 
Hearing applause and universal shout ||comma||

Whether these pearls of praise be his or no ||semicolon||

Such as I am: though for myself alone
I would not be ambitious in my wish ||comma|| 
To wish myself much better ||semicolon|| yet ||comma|| for you
I would be trebled twenty times myself ||semicolon||

SALERIO
Not one ||comma|| my lord ||period|| 
Besides ||comma|| it should appear ||comma|| that if he had
The present money to discharge the Jew ||comma|| 
He would not take it ||period|| Never did I know
A creature ||comma|| that did bear the shape of man ||comma|| 
So keen and greedy to confound a man:
He plies the duke at morning and at night ||comma|| 
And doth impeach the freedom of the state ||comma|| 
If they deny him justice: twenty merchants ||comma|| 
The duke himself ||comma|| and the magnificoes
Of greatest port ||comma|| have all persuaded with him ||semicolon|| 
But none can drive him from the envious plea
Of forfeiture ||comma|| of justice and his bond ||period|| 
When I was with him I have heard him swear
To Tubal and to Chus ||comma|| his countrymen ||comma|| 
That he would rather have Antonio ||single_quote|| s flesh
Than twenty times the value of the sum
That he did owe him: and I know ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| 
If law ||comma|| authority and power deny not ||comma|| 
It will go hard with poor Antonio ||period|| 
Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble ||question_mark|| 
The dearest friend to me ||comma|| the kindest man ||comma|| 
The best-condition ||single_quote|| d and unwearied spirit
In doing courtesies ||comma|| and one in whom

Than any that draws breath in Italy ||period||

Will live as maids and widows ||period|| Come ||comma|| away ||exclamation_mark||

SALERIO
He is ready at the door: he comes ||comma|| my lord ||period||

Shylock ||comma|| the world thinks ||comma|| and I think so too ||comma||

From stubborn Turks and Tartars ||comma|| never train ||single_quote|| d
To offices of tender courtesy ||period|| 
We all expect a gentle answer ||comma|| Jew ||period||

You ||single_quote|| ll ask me ||comma|| why I rather choose to have

But ||comma|| say ||comma|| it is my humour: is it answer ||single_quote|| d ||question_mark||

I pray you ||comma|| think you question with the Jew:
You may as well go stand upon the beach
And bid the main flood bate his usual height ||semicolon|| 
You may as well use question with the wolf
Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb ||semicolon||

CLERK
Your grace shall understand that at the receipt of
your letter I am very sick: but in the instant that
your messenger came ||comma|| in loving visitation was with
me a young doctor of Rome ||semicolon|| his name is Balthasar ||period|| I
acquainted him with the cause in controversy between
the Jew and Antonio the merchant: we turned o ||single_quote|| er
many books together: he is furnished with my
opinion ||semicolon|| which ||comma|| bettered with his own learning ||comma|| the
greatness whereof I cannot enough commend ||comma|| comes
with him ||comma|| at my importunity ||comma|| to fill up your grace ||single_quote|| s
request in my stead ||period|| I beseech you ||comma|| let his lack of
years be no impediment to let him lack a reverend
estimation ||semicolon|| for I never knew so young a body with so
old a head ||period|| I leave him to your gracious
acceptance ||comma|| whose trial shall better publish his
commendation ||period|| 
You hear the learn ||single_quote|| d Bellario ||comma|| what he writes:
And here ||comma|| I take it ||comma|| is the doctor come ||period||

I did ||comma|| my lord ||period|| 
You are welcome: take your place ||period|| 
Are you acquainted with the difference
That holds this present question in the court ||question_mark|| 
I am informed thoroughly of the cause ||period|| 
Which is the merchant here ||comma|| and which the Jew ||question_mark|| 
Antonio and old Shylock ||comma|| both stand forth ||period|| 
Is your name Shylock ||question_mark|| 
Shylock is my name ||period|| 
Of a strange nature is the suit you follow ||semicolon|| 
Yet in such rule that the Venetian law
Cannot impugn you as you do proceed ||period|| 
You stand within his danger ||comma|| do you not ||question_mark|| 
Ay ||comma|| so he says ||period|| 
Do you confess the bond ||question_mark|| 
I do ||period|| 
Then must the Jew be merciful ||period|| 
On what compulsion must I ||question_mark|| tell me that ||period|| 
The quality of mercy is not strain ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven
Upon the place beneath: it is twice blest ||semicolon|| 
It blesseth him that gives and him that takes:
 ||single_quote|| Tis mightiest in the mightiest: it becomes
The throned monarch better than his crown ||semicolon|| 
His sceptre shows the force of temporal power ||comma|| 
The attribute to awe and majesty ||comma|| 
Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings ||semicolon|| 
But mercy is above this sceptred sway ||semicolon|| 
It is enthroned in the hearts of kings ||comma|| 
It is an attribute to God himself ||semicolon|| 
And earthly power doth then show likest God ||single_quote|| s
When mercy seasons justice ||period|| Therefore ||comma|| Jew ||comma|| 
Though justice be thy plea ||comma|| consider this ||comma|| 
That ||comma|| in the course of justice ||comma|| none of us
Should see salvation: we do pray for mercy ||semicolon|| 
And that same prayer doth teach us all to render
The deeds of mercy ||period|| I have spoke thus much

I am never merry when I hear sweet music ||period|| 
The reason is ||comma|| your spirits are attentive:
For do but note a wild and wanton herd ||comma|| 
Or race of youthful and unhandled colts ||comma|| 
Fetching mad bounds ||comma|| bellowing and neighing loud ||comma|| 
Which is the hot condition of their blood ||semicolon|| 
If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound ||comma|| 
Or any air of music touch their ears ||comma|| 
You shall perceive them make a mutual stand ||comma|| 
Their savage eyes turn ||single_quote|| d to a modest gaze
By the sweet power of music: therefore the poet
Did feign that Orpheus drew trees ||comma|| stones and floods ||semicolon|| 
Since nought so stockish ||comma|| hard and full of rage ||comma|| 
But music for the time doth change his nature ||period|| 
The man that hath no music in himself ||comma|| 
Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds ||comma|| 
Is fit for treasons ||comma|| stratagems and spoils ||semicolon|| 
The motions of his spirit are dull as night
And his affections dark as Erebus:
Let no such man be trusted ||period|| Mark the music ||period|| 
That light we see is burning in my hall ||period|| 
How far that little candle throws his beams ||exclamation_mark|| 
So shines a good deed in a naughty world ||period|| 
When the moon shone ||comma|| we did not see the candle ||period||

FIRST SENATOR

Look to her ||comma|| Moor ||comma|| if thou hast eyes to see:
She has deceived her father ||comma|| and may thee ||period|| 
My life upon her faith ||exclamation_mark|| Honest Iago ||comma|| 
My Desdemona must I leave to thee:
I prithee ||comma|| let thy wife attend on her:
And bring them after in the best advantage ||period|| 
Come ||comma|| Desdemona: I have but an hour
Of love ||comma|| of worldly matters and direction ||comma|| 
To spend with thee: we must obey the time ||period|| 
Iago ||comma|| ||dash|| 
What say ||single_quote|| st thou ||comma|| noble heart ||question_mark|| 
What will I do ||comma|| thinkest thou ||question_mark|| 
Why ||comma|| go to bed ||comma|| and sleep ||period|| 
I will incontinently drown myself ||period|| 
If thou dost ||comma|| I shall never love thee after ||period|| Why ||comma|| 
thou silly gentleman ||exclamation_mark|| 
It is silliness to live when to live is torment ||semicolon|| and
then have we a prescription to die when death is our physician ||period|| 
O villainous ||exclamation_mark|| I have looked upon the world for four
times seven years ||semicolon|| and since I could distinguish
betwixt a benefit and an injury ||comma|| I never found man
that knew how to love himself ||period|| Ere I would say ||comma|| I
would drown myself for the love of a guinea-hen ||comma|| I
would change my humanity with a baboon ||period|| 
What should I do ||question_mark|| I confess it is my shame to be so
fond ||semicolon|| but it is not in my virtue to amend it ||period|| 
Virtue ||exclamation_mark|| a fig ||exclamation_mark|| ||single_quote|| tis in ourselves that we are thus
or thus ||period|| Our bodies are our gardens ||comma|| to the which
our wills are gardeners: so that if we will plant
nettles ||comma|| or sow lettuce ||comma|| set hyssop and weed up
thyme ||comma|| supply it with one gender of herbs ||comma|| or
distract it with many ||comma|| either to have it sterile
with idleness ||comma|| or manured with industry ||comma|| why ||comma|| the
power and corrigible authority of this lies in our
wills ||period|| If the balance of our lives had not one
scale of reason to poise another of sensuality ||comma|| the
blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us
to most preposterous conclusions: but we have
reason to cool our raging motions ||comma|| our carnal
stings ||comma|| our unbitted lusts ||comma|| whereof I take this that
you call love to be a sect or scion ||period|| 
It cannot be ||period|| 
It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of
the will ||period|| Come ||comma|| be a man ||period|| Drown thyself ||exclamation_mark|| drown
cats and blind puppies ||period|| I have professed me thy
friend and I confess me knit to thy deserving with
cables of perdurable toughness ||semicolon|| I could never
better stead thee than now ||period|| Put money in thy
purse ||semicolon|| follow thou the wars ||semicolon|| defeat thy favour with
an usurped beard ||semicolon|| I say ||comma|| put money in thy purse ||period|| It
cannot be that Desdemona should long continue her
love to the Moor ||comma|| ||dash|| put money in thy purse ||comma|| ||dash|| nor he
his to her: it was a violent commencement ||comma|| and thou
shalt see an answerable sequestration: ||dash|| put but
money in thy purse ||period|| These Moors are changeable in
their wills: fill thy purse with money: ||dash|| the food
that to him now is as luscious as locusts ||comma|| shall be
to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida ||period|| She must
change for youth: when she is sated with his body ||comma|| 
she will find the error of her choice: she must
have change ||comma|| she must: therefore put money in thy
purse ||period|| If thou wilt needs damn thyself ||comma|| do it a
more delicate way than drowning ||period|| Make all the money
thou canst: if sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt
an erring barbarian and a supersubtle Venetian not
too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell ||comma|| thou
shalt enjoy her ||semicolon|| therefore make money ||period|| A pox of
drowning thyself ||exclamation_mark|| it is clean out of the way: seek
thou rather to be hanged in compassing thy joy than
to be drowned and go without her ||period|| 
Wilt thou be fast to my hopes ||comma|| if I depend on
the issue ||question_mark|| 
Thou art sure of me: ||dash|| go ||comma|| make money: ||dash|| I have told
thee often ||comma|| and I re-tell thee again and again ||comma|| I
hate the Moor: my cause is hearted ||semicolon|| thine hath no
less reason ||period|| Let us be conjunctive in our revenge
against him: if thou canst cuckold him ||comma|| thou dost
thyself a pleasure ||comma|| me a sport ||period|| There are many
events in the womb of time which will be delivered ||period|| 
Traverse ||exclamation_mark|| go ||comma|| provide thy money ||period|| We will have more
of this to-morrow ||period|| Adieu ||period|| 
Where shall we meet i ||single_quote|| the morning ||question_mark|| 
At my lodging ||period|| 
I ||single_quote|| ll be with thee betimes ||period|| 
Go to ||semicolon|| farewell ||period|| Do you hear ||comma|| Roderigo ||question_mark|| 
What say you ||question_mark|| 
No more of drowning ||comma|| do you hear ||question_mark|| 
I am changed: I ||single_quote|| ll go sell all my land ||period|| 
Thus do I ever make my fool my purse:
For I mine own gain ||single_quote|| d knowledge should profane ||comma|| 
If I would time expend with such a snipe ||period|| 
But for my sport and profit ||period|| I hate the Moor:
And it is thought abroad ||comma|| that ||single_quote|| twixt my sheets
He has done my office: I know not if ||single_quote|| t be true ||semicolon|| 
But I ||comma|| for mere suspicion in that kind ||comma|| 
Will do as if for surety ||period|| He holds me well ||semicolon|| 
The better shall my purpose work on him ||period|| 
Cassio ||single_quote|| s a proper man: let me see now:
To get his place and to plume up my will
In double knavery ||dash|| How ||comma|| how ||question_mark|| Let ||single_quote|| s see: ||dash|| 
After some time ||comma|| to abuse Othello ||single_quote|| s ear
That he is too familiar with his wife ||period|| 
He hath a person and a smooth dispose
To be suspected ||comma|| framed to make women false ||period|| 
The Moor is of a free and open nature ||comma|| 
That thinks men honest that but seem to be so ||comma|| 
And will as tenderly be led by the nose
As asses are ||period|| 
I have ||single_quote|| t ||period|| It is engender ||single_quote|| d ||period|| Hell and night
Must bring this monstrous birth to the world ||single_quote|| s light ||period|| 
What from the cape can you discern at sea ||question_mark|| 
FIRST GENTLEMAN
Nothing at all: it is a highwrought flood ||semicolon|| 
I cannot ||comma|| ||single_quote|| twixt the heaven and the main ||comma|| 
Descry a sail ||period|| 
Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land ||semicolon|| 
A fuller blast ne ||single_quote|| er shook our battlements:
If it hath ruffian ||single_quote|| d so upon the sea ||comma|| 
What ribs of oak ||comma|| when mountains melt on them ||comma|| 
Can hold the mortise ||question_mark|| What shall we hear of this ||question_mark|| 
SECOND GENTLEMAN
A segregation of the Turkish fleet:
For do but stand upon the foaming shore ||comma|| 
The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds ||semicolon|| 
The wind-shaked surge ||comma|| with high and monstrous mane ||comma|| 
seems to cast water on the burning bear ||comma|| 
And quench the guards of the ever-fixed pole:
I never did like molestation view
On the enchafed flood ||period|| 
If that the Turkish fleet
Be not enshelter ||single_quote|| d and embay ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| they are drown ||single_quote|| d:
It is impossible they bear it out ||period|| 
THIRD GENTLEMAN
News ||comma|| lads ||exclamation_mark|| our wars are done ||period|| 
The desperate tempest hath so bang ||single_quote|| d the Turks ||comma|| 
That their designment halts: a noble ship of Venice
Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance
On most part of their fleet ||period|| 
How ||exclamation_mark|| is this true ||question_mark|| 
THIRD GENTLEMAN
The ship is here put in ||comma|| 
A Veronesa ||semicolon|| Michael Cassio ||comma||

With foul and violent tempest ||period||

Herald
It is Othello ||single_quote|| s pleasure ||comma|| our noble and valiant
general ||comma|| that ||comma|| upon certain tidings now arrived ||comma|| 
importing the mere perdition of the Turkish fleet ||comma|| 
every man put himself into triumph ||semicolon|| some to dance ||comma|| 
some to make bonfires ||comma|| each man to what sport and
revels his addiction leads him: for ||comma|| besides these
beneficial news ||comma|| it is the celebration of his
nuptial ||period|| So much was his pleasure should be
proclaimed ||period|| All offices are open ||comma|| and there is full
liberty of feasting from this present hour of five
till the bell have told eleven ||period|| Heaven bless the
isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello ||exclamation_mark|| 
Good Michael ||comma|| look you to the guard to-night:
Let ||single_quote|| s teach ourselves that honourable stop ||comma|| 
Not to outsport discretion ||period|| 
Iago hath direction what to do ||semicolon||

GENTLEMAN
My lord ||comma|| stand back ||comma|| and let the coffin pass ||period||

And spurn upon thee ||comma|| beggar ||comma|| for thy boldness ||period|| 
What ||comma|| do you tremble ||question_mark|| are you all afraid ||question_mark||

And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil ||period|| 
Avaunt ||comma|| thou dreadful minister of hell ||exclamation_mark|| 
Thou hadst but power over his mortal body ||comma|| 
His soul thou canst not have ||semicolon|| therefore be gone ||period|| 
Sweet saint ||comma|| for charity ||comma|| be not so curst ||period|| 
Foul devil ||comma|| for God ||single_quote|| s sake ||comma|| hence ||comma|| and trouble us not ||semicolon|| 
For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell ||comma|| 
Fill ||single_quote|| d it with cursing cries and deep exclaims ||period|| 
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds ||comma|| 
Behold this pattern of thy butcheries ||period|| 
O ||comma|| gentlemen ||comma|| see ||comma|| see ||exclamation_mark|| dead Henry ||single_quote|| s wounds
Open their congeal ||single_quote|| d mouths and bleed afresh ||exclamation_mark|| 
Blush ||comma|| Blush ||comma|| thou lump of foul deformity ||semicolon|| 
For ||single_quote|| tis thy presence that exhales this blood
From cold and empty veins ||comma|| where no blood dwells ||semicolon|| 
Thy deed ||comma|| inhuman and unnatural ||comma|| 
Provokes this deluge most unnatural ||period|| 
O God ||comma|| which this blood madest ||comma|| revenge his death ||exclamation_mark|| 
O earth ||comma|| which this blood drink ||single_quote|| st revenge his death ||exclamation_mark|| 
Either heaven with lightning strike the
murderer dead ||comma|| 
Or earth ||comma|| gape open wide and eat him quick ||comma|| 
As thou dost swallow up this good king ||single_quote|| s blood
Which his hell-govern ||single_quote|| d arm hath butchered ||exclamation_mark|| 
Lady ||comma|| you know no rules of charity ||comma|| 
Which renders good for bad ||comma|| blessings for curses ||period|| 
Villain ||comma|| thou know ||single_quote|| st no law of God nor man:
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity ||period|| 
But I know none ||comma|| and therefore am no beast ||period|| 
O wonderful ||comma|| when devils tell the truth ||exclamation_mark|| 
More wonderful ||comma|| when angels are so angry ||period||

CARDINAL
My Lord of Buckingham ||comma|| if my weak oratory
Can from his mother win the Duke of York ||comma|| 
Anon expect him here ||semicolon|| but if she be obdurate
To mild entreaties ||comma|| God in heaven forbid
We should infringe the holy privilege
Of blessed sanctuary ||exclamation_mark|| not for all this land
Would I be guilty of so deep a sin ||period|| 
You are too senseless ||dash|| obstinate ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| 
Too ceremonious and traditional
Weigh it but with the grossness of this age ||comma|| 
You break not sanctuary in seizing him ||period|| 
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those whose dealings have deserved the place ||comma|| 
And those who have the wit to claim the place:
This prince hath neither claim ||single_quote|| d it nor deserved it ||semicolon|| 
And therefore ||comma|| in mine opinion ||comma|| cannot have it:
Then ||comma|| taking him from thence that is not there ||comma|| 
You break no privilege nor charter there ||period||

But sanctuary children ne ||single_quote|| er till now ||period||

And you my good lords ||comma|| both have well proceeded ||comma||

I never look ||single_quote|| d for better at his hands ||comma|| 
After he once fell in with Mistress Shore ||period|| 
Yet had not we determined he should die ||comma|| 
Until your lordship came to see his death ||semicolon|| 
Which now the loving haste of these our friends ||comma|| 
Somewhat against our meaning ||comma|| have prevented:
Because ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| we would have had you heard
The traitor speak ||comma|| and timorously confess
The manner and the purpose of his treason ||semicolon|| 
That you might well have signified the same
Unto the citizens ||comma|| who haply may
Misconstrue us in him and wail his death ||period|| 
Lord Mayor
But ||comma|| my good lord ||comma|| your grace ||single_quote|| s word shall serve ||comma|| 
As well as I had seen and heard him speak
And doubt you not ||comma|| right noble princes both ||comma|| 
But I ||single_quote|| ll acquaint our duteous citizens
With all your just proceedings in this cause ||period|| 
And to that end we wish ||single_quote|| d your lord-ship here ||comma|| 
To avoid the carping censures of the world ||period|| 
But since you come too late of our intents ||comma|| 
Yet witness what you hear we did intend:
And so ||comma|| my good lord mayor ||comma|| we bid farewell ||period|| 
Go ||comma|| after ||comma|| after ||comma|| cousin Buckingham ||period|| 
The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post:
There ||comma|| at your meet ||single_quote|| st advantage of the time ||comma|| 
Infer the bastardy of Edward ||single_quote|| s children:
Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen ||comma|| 
Only for saying he would make his son
Heir to the crown ||semicolon|| meaning indeed his house ||comma|| 
Which ||comma|| by the sign thereof was termed so ||period|| 
Moreover ||comma|| urge his hateful luxury
And bestial appetite in change of lust ||semicolon|| 
Which stretched to their servants ||comma|| daughters ||comma|| wives ||comma|| 
Even where his lustful eye or savage heart ||comma|| 
Without control ||comma|| listed to make his prey ||period|| 
Nay ||comma|| for a need ||comma|| thus far come near my person:
Tell them ||comma|| when that my mother went with child
Of that unsatiate Edward ||comma|| noble York
My princely father then had wars in France
And ||comma|| by just computation of the time ||comma|| 
Found that the issue was not his begot ||semicolon|| 
Which well appeared in his lineaments ||comma|| 
Being nothing like the noble duke my father:
But touch this sparingly ||comma|| as ||single_quote|| twere far off ||comma|| 
Because you know ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| my mother lives ||period|| 
Fear not ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| I ||single_quote|| ll play the orator

Were for myself: and so ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| adieu ||period|| 
If you thrive well ||comma|| bring them to Baynard ||single_quote|| s Castle ||semicolon|| 
Where you shall find me well accompanied
With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops ||period|| 
I go: and towards three or four o ||single_quote|| clock
Look for the news that the Guildhall affords ||period|| 
Go ||comma|| Lovel ||comma|| with all speed to Doctor Shaw ||semicolon|| 
Go thou to Friar Penker ||semicolon|| bid them both
Meet me within this hour at Baynard ||single_quote|| s Castle ||period|| 
Now will I in ||comma|| to take some privy order ||comma|| 
To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight ||semicolon|| 
And to give notice ||comma|| that no manner of person
At any time have recourse unto the princes ||period||

This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings ||semicolon|| 
Which in a set hand fairly is engross ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
That it may be this day read over in Paul ||single_quote|| s ||period|| 
And mark how well the sequel hangs together:
Eleven hours I spent to write it over ||comma|| 
For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me ||semicolon|| 
The precedent was full as long a-doing:
And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings ||comma|| 
Untainted ||comma|| unexamined ||comma|| free ||comma|| at liberty
Here ||single_quote|| s a good world the while ||exclamation_mark|| Why who ||single_quote|| s so gross ||comma|| 
That seeth not this palpable device ||question_mark|| 
Yet who ||single_quote|| s so blind ||comma|| but says he sees it not ||question_mark|| 
Bad is the world ||semicolon|| and all will come to nought ||comma|| 
When such bad dealings must be seen in thought ||period||

Touch ||single_quote|| d you the bastardy of Edward ||single_quote|| s children ||question_mark|| 
I did ||semicolon|| with his contract with Lady Lucy ||comma||

The insatiate greediness of his desires ||comma||

His tyranny for trifles ||semicolon|| his own bastardy ||comma|| 
As being got ||comma|| your father then in France ||comma|| 
His resemblance ||comma|| being not like the duke ||semicolon|| 
Withal I did infer your lineaments ||comma|| 
Being the right idea of your father ||comma|| 
Both in your form and nobleness of mind ||semicolon|| 
Laid open all your victories in Scotland ||comma||

My lord ||comma||

At our entreaties ||comma|| to amend that fault ||exclamation_mark||

The supreme seat ||comma|| the throne majestical ||comma||

Which here we waken to our country ||single_quote|| s good ||comma|| 
This noble isle doth want her proper limbs ||semicolon|| 
Her face defaced with scars of infamy ||comma|| 
Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants ||comma||

Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion ||period|| 
Which to recure ||comma|| we heartily solicit
Your gracious self to take on you the charge
And kingly government of this your land ||comma|| 
Not as protector ||comma|| steward ||comma|| substitute ||comma|| 
Or lowly factor for another ||single_quote|| s gain ||semicolon|| 
But as successively from blood to blood ||comma|| 
Your right of birth ||comma|| your empery ||comma|| your own ||period|| 
For this ||comma|| consorted with the citizens ||comma||

And by their vehement instigation ||comma|| 
In this just suit come I to move your grace ||period|| 
I know not whether to depart in silence ||comma|| 
Or bitterly to speak in your reproof ||period|| 
Best fitteth my degree or your condition
If not to answer ||comma|| you might haply think
Tongue-tied ambition ||comma|| not replying ||comma|| yielded
To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty ||comma|| 
Which fondly you would here impose on me ||semicolon||

So season ||single_quote|| d with your faithful love to me ||period|| 
Then ||comma|| on the other side ||comma|| I cheque ||single_quote|| d my friends ||period|| 
Therefore ||comma|| to speak ||comma|| and to avoid the first ||comma|| 
And then ||comma|| in speaking ||comma|| not to incur the last ||comma|| 
Definitively thus I answer you ||period|| 
Your love deserves my thanks ||semicolon|| but my desert
Unmeritable shuns your high request ||period|| 
First if all obstacles were cut away ||comma|| 
And that my path were even to the crown ||comma|| 
As my ripe revenue and due by birth
Yet so much is my poverty of spirit ||comma|| 
So mighty and so many my defects ||comma|| 
As I had rather hide me from my greatness ||comma|| 
Being a bark to brook no mighty sea ||comma||

And in the vapour of my glory smother ||single_quote|| d ||period||

And make ||comma|| no doubt ||comma|| us happy by his reign ||period||

My lord ||comma|| this argues conscience in your grace ||semicolon||

All circumstances well considered ||period||

There is no other way

And not be Richard that hath done all this ||period|| 
Say that I did all this for love of her ||period|| 
Nay ||comma|| then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee ||comma|| 
Having bought love with such a bloody spoil ||period|| 
Look ||comma|| what is done cannot be now amended:
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes ||comma|| 
Which after hours give leisure to repent ||period|| 
If I did take the kingdom from your sons ||comma|| 
To make amends ||comma|| Ill give it to your daughter ||period||

They are as children but one step below ||comma|| 
Even of your mettle ||comma|| of your very blood ||semicolon|| 
Of an one pain ||comma|| save for a night of groans
Endured of her ||comma|| for whom you bid like sorrow ||period|| 
Your children were vexation to your youth ||comma|| 
But mine shall be a comfort to your age ||period|| 
The loss you have is but a son being king ||comma|| 
And by that loss your daughter is made queen ||period|| 
I cannot make you what amends I would ||comma|| 
Therefore accept such kindness as I can ||period|| 
Dorset your son ||comma|| that with a fearful soul
Leads discontented steps in foreign soil ||comma|| 
This fair alliance quickly shall call home
To high promotions and great dignity:
The king ||comma|| that calls your beauteous daughter wife ||period||

As he is but my father ||single_quote|| s brother ||single_quote|| s son ||comma||

He is our subject ||comma|| Mowbray ||semicolon|| so art thou:

Then ||comma|| Bolingbroke ||comma|| as low as to thy heart ||comma|| 
Through the false passage of thy throat ||comma|| thou liest ||period|| 
Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais
Disbursed I duly to his highness ||single_quote|| soldiers ||semicolon|| 
The other part reserved I by consent ||comma|| 
For that my sovereign liege was in my debt
Upon remainder of a dear account ||comma|| 
Since last I went to France to fetch his queen:
Now swallow down that lie ||period|| For Gloucester ||single_quote|| s death ||comma|| 
I slew him not ||semicolon|| but to my own disgrace
Neglected my sworn duty in that case ||period|| 
For you ||comma|| my noble Lord of Lancaster ||comma|| 
The honourable father to my foe
Once did I lay an ambush for your life ||comma|| 
A trespass that doth vex my grieved soul
But ere I last received the sacrament
I did confess it ||comma|| and exactly begg ||single_quote|| d
Your grace ||single_quote|| s pardon ||comma|| and I hope I had it ||period|| 
This is my fault: as for the rest appeall ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
It issues from the rancour of a villain ||comma|| 
A recreant and most degenerate traitor
Which in myself I boldly will defend ||semicolon|| 
And interchangeably hurl down my gage
Upon this overweening traitor ||single_quote|| s foot ||comma|| 
To prove myself a loyal gentleman
Even in the best blood chamber ||single_quote|| d in his bosom ||period|| 
In haste whereof ||comma|| most heartily I pray
Your highness to assign our trial day ||period|| 
Wrath-kindled gentlemen ||comma|| be ruled by me ||semicolon||

This we prescribe ||comma|| though no physician ||semicolon|| 
Deep malice makes too deep incision ||semicolon||

The one my duty owes ||semicolon|| but my fair name ||comma||

Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame ||period||

And I resign my gage ||period|| My dear dear lord ||comma|| 
The purest treasure mortal times afford
Is spotless reputation: that away ||comma|| 
Men are but gilded loam or painted clay ||period||

Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast ||period||

FIRST HERALD
Harry of Hereford ||comma|| Lancaster and Derby ||comma|| 
Stands here for God ||comma|| his sovereign and himself ||comma|| 
On pain to be found false and recreant ||comma|| 
To prove the Duke of Norfolk ||comma|| Thomas Mowbray ||comma|| 
A traitor to his God ||comma|| his king and him ||semicolon|| 
And dares him to set forward to the fight ||period|| 
SECOND HERALD
Here standeth Thomas Mowbray ||comma|| Duke of Norfolk ||comma|| 
On pain to be found false and recreant ||comma|| 
Both to defend himself and to approve
Henry of Hereford ||comma|| Lancaster ||comma|| and Derby ||comma|| 
To God ||comma|| his sovereign and to him disloyal ||semicolon|| 
Courageously and with a free desire
Attending but the signal to begin ||period|| 
LORD MARSHAL
Sound ||comma|| trumpets ||semicolon|| and set forward ||comma|| combatants ||period|| 
Stay ||comma|| the king hath thrown his warder down ||period|| 
Let them lay by their helmets and their spears ||comma|| 
And both return back to their chairs again:
Withdraw with us: and let the trumpets sound
While we return these dukes what we decree ||period|| 
Draw near ||comma|| 
And list what with our council we have done ||period|| 
For that our kingdom ||single_quote|| s earth should not be soil ||single_quote|| d
With that dear blood which it hath fostered ||semicolon|| 
And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect
Of civil wounds plough ||single_quote|| d up with neighbours ||single_quote|| sword ||semicolon|| 
And for we think the eagle-winged pride
Of sky-aspiring and ambitious thoughts ||comma|| 
With rival-hating envy ||comma|| set on you
To wake our peace ||comma|| which in our country ||single_quote|| s cradle
Draws the sweet infant breath of gentle sleep ||semicolon|| 
Which so roused up with boisterous untuned drums ||comma|| 
With harsh resounding trumpets ||single_quote|| dreadful bray ||comma|| 
And grating shock of wrathful iron arms ||comma|| 
Might from our quiet confines fright fair peace
And make us wade even in our kindred ||single_quote|| s blood ||comma|| 
Therefore ||comma|| we banish you our territories:
You ||comma|| cousin Hereford ||comma|| upon pain of life ||comma|| 
Till twice five summers have enrich ||single_quote|| d our fields
Shall not regreet our fair dominions ||comma|| 
But tread the stranger paths of banishment ||period|| 
Your will be done: this must my comfort be ||comma|| 
Sun that warms you here shall shine on me ||semicolon|| 
And those his golden beams to you here lent
Shall point on me and gild my banishment ||period|| 
Norfolk ||comma|| for thee remains a heavier doom ||comma|| 
Which I with some unwillingness pronounce:
The sly slow hours shall not determinate
The dateless limit of thy dear exile ||semicolon|| 
The hopeless word of ||single_quote|| never to return ||single_quote|| 
Breathe I against thee ||comma|| upon pain of life ||period|| 
A heavy sentence ||comma|| my most sovereign liege ||comma|| 
And all unlook ||single_quote|| d for from your highness ||single_quote|| mouth:
A dearer merit ||comma|| not so deep a maim
As to be cast forth in the common air ||comma|| 
Have I deserved at your highness ||single_quote|| hands ||period|| 
The language I have learn ||single_quote|| d these forty years ||comma|| 
My native English ||comma|| now I must forego:
And now my tongue ||single_quote|| s use is to me no more
Than an unstringed viol or a harp ||comma|| 
Or like a cunning instrument cased up ||comma|| 
Or ||comma|| being open ||comma|| put into his hands
That knows no touch to tune the harmony:
Within my mouth you have engaol ||single_quote|| d my tongue ||comma|| 
Doubly portcullis ||single_quote|| d with my teeth and lips ||semicolon|| 
And dull unfeeling barren ignorance
Is made my gaoler to attend on me ||period|| 
I am too old to fawn upon a nurse ||comma|| 
Too far in years to be a pupil now:
What is thy sentence then but speechless death ||comma|| 
Which robs my tongue from breathing native breath ||question_mark|| 
It boots thee not to be compassionate:
After our sentence plaining comes too late ||period|| 
Then thus I turn me from my country ||single_quote|| s light ||comma|| 
To dwell in solemn shades of endless night ||period|| 
Return again ||comma|| and take an oath with thee ||period|| 
Lay on our royal sword your banish ||single_quote|| d hands ||semicolon|| 
Swear by the duty that you owe to God ||dash|| 
Our part therein we banish with yourselves ||dash|| 
To keep the oath that we administer:
You never shall ||comma|| so help you truth and God ||exclamation_mark|| 
Embrace each other ||single_quote|| s love in banishment ||semicolon|| 
Nor never look upon each other ||single_quote|| s face ||semicolon|| 
Nor never write ||comma|| regreet ||comma|| nor reconcile
This louring tempest of your home-bred hate ||semicolon|| 
Nor never by advised purpose meet
To plot ||comma|| contrive ||comma|| or complot any ill

I swear ||period|| 
And I ||comma|| to keep all this ||period|| 
Norfolk ||comma|| so far as to mine enemy: ||dash|| 
By this time ||comma|| had the king permitted us ||comma|| 
One of our souls had wander ||single_quote|| d in the air ||period|| 
Banish ||single_quote|| d this frail sepulchre of our flesh ||comma|| 
As now our flesh is banish ||single_quote|| d from this land:
Confess thy treasons ere thou fly the realm ||semicolon|| 
Since thou hast far to go ||comma|| bear not along
The clogging burthen of a guilty soul ||period|| 
No ||comma|| Bolingbroke: if ever I were traitor ||comma|| 
My name be blotted from the book of life ||comma|| 
And I from heaven banish ||single_quote|| d as from hence ||exclamation_mark|| 
But what thou art ||comma|| God ||comma|| thou ||comma|| and I do know ||semicolon|| 
And all too soon ||comma|| I fear ||comma|| the king shall rue ||period|| 
Farewell ||comma|| my liege ||period|| Now no way can I stray ||semicolon|| 
Save back to England ||comma|| all the world ||single_quote|| s my way ||period|| 
Uncle ||comma|| even in the glasses of thine eyes
I see thy grieved heart: thy sad aspect
Hath from the number of his banish ||single_quote|| d years
Pluck ||single_quote|| d four away ||period|| 
Six frozen winter spent ||comma|| 
Return with welcome home from banishment ||period|| 
How long a time lies in one little word ||exclamation_mark|| 
Four lagging winters and four wanton springs
End in a word: such is the breath of kings ||period|| 
I thank my liege ||comma|| that in regard of me
He shortens four years of my son ||single_quote|| s exile:
But little vantage shall I reap thereby ||semicolon|| 
For ||comma|| ere the six years that he hath to spend
Can change their moons and bring their times about
My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light
Shall be extinct with age and endless night ||semicolon|| 
My inch of taper will be burnt and done ||comma|| 
And blindfold death not let me see my son ||period|| 
Why uncle ||comma|| thou hast many years to live ||period|| 
But not a minute ||comma|| king ||comma|| that thou canst give:
Shorten my days thou canst with sullen sorrow ||comma|| 
And pluck nights from me ||comma|| but not lend a morrow ||semicolon|| 
Thou canst help time to furrow me with age ||comma|| 
But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage ||semicolon|| 
Thy word is current with him for my death ||comma|| 
But dead ||comma|| thy kingdom cannot buy my breath ||period|| 
Thy son is banish ||single_quote|| d upon good advice ||comma|| 
Whereto thy tongue a party-verdict gave:
Why at our justice seem ||single_quote|| st thou then to lour ||question_mark|| 
Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour ||period|| 
You urged me as a judge ||semicolon|| but I had rather
You would have bid me argue like a father ||period|| 
O ||comma|| had it been a stranger ||comma|| not my child ||comma|| 
To smooth his fault I should have been more mild:
A partial slander sought I to avoid ||comma|| 
And in the sentence my own life destroy ||single_quote|| d ||period|| 
Alas ||comma|| I look ||single_quote|| d when some of you should say ||comma|| 
I was too strict to make mine own away ||semicolon|| 
But you gave leave to my unwilling tongue
Against my will to do myself this wrong ||period|| 
Cousin ||comma|| farewell ||semicolon|| and ||comma|| uncle ||comma|| bid him so:
Six years we banish him ||comma|| and he shall go ||period|| 
Cousin ||comma|| farewell: what presence must not know ||comma|| 
From where you do remain let paper show ||period|| 
LORD MARSHAL
My lord ||comma|| no leave take I ||semicolon|| for I will ride ||comma|| 
As far as land will let me ||comma|| by your side ||period|| 
O ||comma|| to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words ||comma|| 
That thou return ||single_quote|| st no greeting to thy friends ||question_mark|| 
I have too few to take my leave of you ||comma|| 
When the tongue ||single_quote|| s office should be prodigal
To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart ||period|| 
Thy grief is but thy absence for a time ||period|| 
Joy absent ||comma|| grief is present for that time ||period|| 
What is six winters ||question_mark|| they are quickly gone ||period|| 
To men in joy ||semicolon|| but grief makes one hour ten ||period|| 
Call it a travel that thou takest for pleasure ||period|| 
My heart will sigh when I miscall it so ||comma|| 
Which finds it an inforced pilgrimage ||period|| 
The sullen passage of thy weary steps
Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set
The precious jewel of thy home return ||period|| 
Nay ||comma|| rather ||comma|| every tedious stride I make
Will but remember me what a deal of world
I wander from the jewels that I love ||period|| 
Must I not serve a long apprenticehood
To foreign passages ||comma|| and in the end ||comma|| 
Having my freedom ||comma|| boast of nothing else
But that I was a journeyman to grief ||question_mark|| 
All places that the eye of heaven visits
Are to a wise man ports and happy havens ||period|| 
Teach thy necessity to reason thus ||semicolon|| 
There is no virtue like necessity ||period|| 
Think not the king did banish thee ||comma|| 
But thou the king ||period|| Woe doth the heavier sit ||comma|| 
Where it perceives it is but faintly borne ||period|| 
Go ||comma|| say I sent thee forth to purchase honour
And not the king exiled thee ||semicolon|| or suppose
Devouring pestilence hangs in our air
And thou art flying to a fresher clime:
Look ||comma|| what thy soul holds dear ||comma|| imagine it
To lie that way thou go ||single_quote|| st ||comma|| not whence thou comest:
Suppose the singing birds musicians ||comma|| 
The grass whereon thou tread ||single_quote|| st the presence strew ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
The flowers fair ladies ||comma|| and thy steps no more
Than a delightful measure or a dance ||semicolon|| 
For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite
The man that mocks at it and sets it light ||period|| 
O ||comma|| who can hold a fire in his hand
By thinking on the frosty Caucasus ||question_mark|| 
Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite
By bare imagination of a feast ||question_mark|| 
Or wallow naked in December snow
By thinking on fantastic summer ||single_quote|| s heat ||question_mark|| 
O ||comma|| no ||exclamation_mark|| the apprehension of the good
Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:
Fell sorrow ||single_quote|| s tooth doth never rankle more
Than when he bites ||comma|| but lanceth not the sore ||period|| 
Come ||comma|| come ||comma|| my son ||comma|| I ||single_quote|| ll bring thee on thy way:
Had I thy youth and cause ||comma|| I would not stay ||period|| 
Then ||comma|| England ||single_quote|| s ground ||comma|| farewell ||semicolon|| sweet soil ||comma|| adieu ||semicolon|| 
My mother ||comma|| and my nurse ||comma|| that bears me yet ||exclamation_mark|| 
Where ||single_quote|| er I wander ||comma|| boast of this I can ||comma|| 
Though banish ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| yet a trueborn Englishman ||period|| 
We did observe ||period|| Cousin Aumerle ||comma|| 
How far brought you high Hereford on his way ||question_mark|| 
I brought high Hereford ||comma|| if you call him so ||comma|| 
But to the next highway ||comma|| and there I left him ||period|| 
And say ||comma|| what store of parting tears were shed ||question_mark|| 
Faith ||comma|| none for me ||semicolon|| except the north-east wind ||comma|| 
Which then blew bitterly against our faces ||comma|| 
Awaked the sleeping rheum ||comma|| and so by chance
Did grace our hollow parting with a tear ||period|| 
What said our cousin when you parted with him ||question_mark|| 
 ||single_quote|| Farewell: ||single_quote|| 
And ||comma|| for my heart disdained that my tongue
Should so profane the word ||comma|| that taught me craft
To counterfeit oppression of such grief
That words seem ||single_quote|| d buried in my sorrow ||single_quote|| s grave ||period|| 
Marry ||comma|| would the word ||single_quote|| farewell ||single_quote|| have lengthen ||single_quote|| d hours
And added years to his short banishment ||comma|| 
He should have had a volume of farewells ||semicolon|| 
But since it would not ||comma|| he had none of me ||period|| 
He is our cousin ||comma|| cousin ||semicolon|| but ||single_quote|| tis doubt ||comma|| 
When time shall call him home from banishment ||comma|| 
Whether our kinsman come to see his friends ||period|| 
Ourself and Bushy ||comma|| Bagot here and Green
Observed his courtship to the common people ||semicolon|| 
How he did seem to dive into their hearts
With humble and familiar courtesy ||comma|| 
What reverence he did throw away on slaves ||comma|| 
Wooing poor craftsmen with the craft of smiles
And patient underbearing of his fortune ||comma|| 
As ||single_quote|| twere to banish their affects with him ||period|| 
Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench ||semicolon|| 
A brace of draymen bid God speed him well
And had the tribute of his supple knee ||comma|| 
With ||single_quote|| Thanks ||comma|| my countrymen ||comma|| my loving friends ||semicolon|| ||single_quote|| 
As were our England in reversion his ||comma|| 
And he our subjects ||single_quote|| next degree in hope ||period|| 
Well ||comma|| he is gone ||semicolon|| and with him go these thoughts ||period|| 
Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland ||comma|| 
Expedient manage must be made ||comma|| my liege ||comma|| 
Ere further leisure yield them further means
For their advantage and your highness ||single_quote|| loss ||period|| 
We will ourself in person to this war:
And ||comma|| for our coffers ||comma|| with too great a court
And liberal largess ||comma|| are grown somewhat light ||comma|| 
We are inforced to farm our royal realm ||semicolon|| 
The revenue whereof shall furnish us
For our affairs in hand: if that come short ||comma|| 
Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters ||semicolon|| 
Whereto ||comma|| when they shall know what men are rich ||comma|| 
They shall subscribe them for large sums of gold
And send them after to supply our wants ||semicolon|| 
For we will make for Ireland presently ||period|| 
Bushy ||comma|| what news ||question_mark|| 
Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick ||comma|| my lord ||comma|| 
Suddenly taken ||semicolon|| and hath sent post haste
To entreat your majesty to visit him ||period|| 
Where lies he ||question_mark|| 
At Ely House ||period|| 
Now put it ||comma|| God ||comma|| in the physician ||single_quote|| s mind
To help him to his grave immediately ||exclamation_mark|| 
The lining of his coffers shall make coats
To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars ||period|| 
Come ||comma|| gentlemen ||comma|| let ||single_quote|| s all go visit him:
Pray God we may make haste ||comma|| and come too late ||exclamation_mark|| 
Will the king come ||comma|| that I may breathe my last
In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth ||question_mark|| 
Vex not yourself ||comma|| nor strive not with your breath ||semicolon|| 
For all in vain comes counsel to his ear ||period|| 
O ||comma|| but they say the tongues of dying men
Enforce attention like deep harmony:
Where words are scarce ||comma|| they are seldom spent in vain ||comma|| 
For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain ||period|| 
He that no more must say is listen ||single_quote|| d more
Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose ||semicolon|| 
More are men ||single_quote|| s ends mark ||single_quote|| d than their lives before:
The setting sun ||comma|| and music at the close ||comma|| 
As the last taste of sweets ||comma|| is sweetest last ||comma|| 
Writ in remembrance more than things long past:
Though Richard my life ||single_quote|| s counsel would not hear ||comma|| 
My death ||single_quote|| s sad tale may yet undeaf his ear ||period|| 
No ||semicolon|| it is stopp ||single_quote|| d with other flattering sounds ||comma|| 
As praises ||comma|| of whose taste the wise are fond ||comma|| 
Lascivious metres ||comma|| to whose venom sound
The open ear of youth doth always listen ||semicolon|| 
Report of fashions in proud Italy ||comma|| 
Whose manners still our tardy apish nation

Methinks I am a prophet new inspired
And thus expiring do foretell of him:
His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last ||comma|| 
For violent fires soon burn out themselves ||semicolon|| 
Small showers last long ||comma|| but sudden storms are short ||semicolon|| 
He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes ||semicolon|| 
With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:
Light vanity ||comma|| insatiate cormorant ||comma|| 
Consuming means ||comma|| soon preys upon itself ||period|| 
This royal throne of kings ||comma|| this scepter ||single_quote|| d isle ||comma|| 
This earth of majesty ||comma|| this seat of Mars ||comma||

This happy breed of men ||comma|| this little world ||comma||

Which serves it in the office of a wall ||comma|| 
Or as a moat defensive to a house ||comma|| 
Against the envy of less happier lands ||comma|| 
This blessed plot ||comma|| this earth ||comma|| this realm ||comma|| this England ||comma||

Of the world ||single_quote|| s ransom ||comma|| blessed Mary ||single_quote|| s Son ||comma|| 
This land of such dear souls ||comma|| this dear dear land ||comma|| 
Dear for her reputation through the world ||comma|| 
Is now leased out ||comma|| I die pronouncing it ||comma|| 
Like to a tenement or pelting farm:
England ||comma|| bound in with the triumphant sea
Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege
Of watery Neptune ||comma|| is now bound in with shame ||comma|| 
With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds:
That England ||comma|| that was wont to conquer others ||comma|| 
Hath made a shameful conquest of itself ||period|| 
Ah ||comma|| would the scandal vanish with my life ||comma|| 
How happy then were my ensuing death ||exclamation_mark|| 
The king is come: deal mildly with his youth ||semicolon|| 
For young hot colts being raged do rage the more ||period||

Old Gaunt indeed ||comma|| and gaunt in being old:
Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast ||semicolon|| 
And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt ||question_mark|| 
For sleeping England long time have I watch ||single_quote|| d ||semicolon|| 
Watching breeds leanness ||comma|| leanness is all gaunt:
The pleasure that some fathers feed upon ||comma|| 
Is my strict fast ||semicolon|| I mean ||comma|| my children ||single_quote|| s looks ||semicolon|| 
And therein fasting ||comma|| hast thou made me gaunt:
Gaunt am I for the grave ||comma|| gaunt as a grave ||comma|| 
Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones ||period|| 
Can sick men play so nicely with their names ||question_mark|| 
No ||comma|| misery makes sport to mock itself:
Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me ||comma|| 
I mock my name ||comma|| great king ||comma|| to flatter thee ||period||

No ||comma|| no ||comma|| men living flatter those that die ||period||

To please the king I did ||semicolon|| to please myself

As my sweet Richard: yet again ||comma|| methinks ||comma||

With nothing trembles: at some thing it grieves ||comma|| 
More than with parting from my lord the king ||period||

The bay-trees in our country are all wither ||single_quote|| d
And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven ||semicolon|| 
The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth
And lean-look ||single_quote|| d prophets whisper fearful change ||semicolon|| 
Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap ||comma|| 
The one in fear to lose what they enjoy ||comma|| 
The other to enjoy by rage and war:
These signs forerun the death or fall of kings ||period|| 
Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled ||comma|| 
As well assured Richard their king is dead ||period|| 
Ah ||comma|| Richard ||comma|| with the eyes of heavy mind
I see thy glory like a shooting star
Fall to the base earth from the firmament ||period|| 
Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west ||comma|| 
Witnessing storms to come ||comma|| woe and unrest:
Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes ||comma|| 
And crossly to thy good all fortune goes ||period|| 
Bring forth these men ||period|| 
Bushy and Green ||comma|| I will not vex your souls ||dash|| 
Since presently your souls must part your bodies ||dash|| 
With too much urging your pernicious lives ||comma|| 
For ||single_quote|| twere no charity ||semicolon|| yet ||comma|| to wash your blood

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
Glad am I that your highness is so arm ||single_quote|| d

Like an unseasonable stormy day ||comma|| 
Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores ||comma|| 
As if the world were all dissolved to tears ||comma||

Of Bolingbroke ||comma|| covering your fearful land
With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel ||period||

No matter where ||semicolon|| of comfort no man speak:

Our lands ||comma|| our lives and all are Bolingbroke ||single_quote|| s ||comma|| 
And nothing can we call our own but death
And that small model of the barren earth
Which serves as paste and cover to our bones ||period|| 
For God ||single_quote|| s sake ||comma|| let us sit upon the ground
And tell sad stories of the death of kings ||semicolon|| 
How some have been deposed ||semicolon|| some slain in war ||comma|| 
Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed ||semicolon|| 
Some poison ||single_quote|| d by their wives: some sleeping kill ||single_quote|| d ||semicolon|| 
All murder ||single_quote|| d: for within the hollow crown
That rounds the mortal temples of a king
Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits ||comma|| 
Scoffing his state and grinning at his pomp ||comma|| 
Allowing him a breath ||comma|| a little scene ||comma|| 
To monarchize ||comma|| be fear ||single_quote|| d and kill with looks ||comma|| 
Infusing him with self and vain conceit ||comma|| 
As if this flesh which walls about our life ||comma|| 
Were brass impregnable ||comma|| and humour ||single_quote|| d thus
Comes at the last and with a little pin
Bores through his castle wall ||comma|| and farewell king ||exclamation_mark|| 
Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood
With solemn reverence: throw away respect ||comma|| 
Tradition ||comma|| form and ceremonious duty ||comma|| 
For you have but mistook me all this while:
I live with bread like you ||comma|| feel want ||comma|| 
Taste grief ||comma|| need friends: subjected thus ||comma|| 
How can you say to me ||comma|| I am a king ||question_mark|| 
My lord ||comma|| wise men ne ||single_quote|| er sit and wail their woes ||comma|| 
But presently prevent the ways to wail ||period|| 
To fear the foe ||comma|| since fear oppresseth strength ||comma|| 
Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe ||comma|| 
And so your follies fight against yourself ||period|| 
Fear and be slain ||semicolon|| no worse can come to fight:
And fight and die is death destroying death ||semicolon|| 
Where fearing dying pays death servile breath ||period|| 
My father hath a power ||semicolon|| inquire of him
And learn to make a body of a limb ||period|| 
Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke ||comma|| I come
To change blows with thee for our day of doom ||period|| 
This ague fit of fear is over-blown ||semicolon|| 
An easy task it is to win our own ||period|| 
Say ||comma|| Scroop ||comma|| where lies our uncle with his power ||question_mark|| 
Speak sweetly ||comma|| man ||comma|| although thy looks be sour ||period|| 
SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
Men judge by the complexion of the sky
The state and inclination of the day:
So may you by my dull and heavy eye ||comma|| 
My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say ||period|| 
I play the torturer ||comma|| by small and small
To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:
Your uncle York is join ||single_quote|| d with Bolingbroke ||comma|| 
And all your northern castles yielded up ||comma|| 
And all your southern gentlemen in arms
Upon his party ||period|| 
Thou hast said enough ||period|| 
Beshrew thee ||comma|| cousin ||comma|| which didst lead me forth
Of that sweet way I was in to despair ||exclamation_mark|| 
What say you now ||question_mark|| what comfort have we now ||question_mark|| 
By heaven ||comma|| I ||single_quote|| ll hate him everlastingly
That bids me be of comfort any more ||period|| 
Go to Flint castle: there I ||single_quote|| ll pine away ||semicolon|| 
A king ||comma|| woe ||single_quote|| s slave ||comma|| shall kingly woe obey ||period|| 
That power I have ||comma|| discharge ||semicolon|| and let them go
To ear the land that hath some hope to grow ||comma|| 
For I have none: let no man speak again
To alter this ||comma|| for counsel is but vain ||period|| 
My liege ||comma|| one word ||period|| 
He does me double wrong
That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue ||period|| 
Discharge my followers: let them hence away ||comma|| 
From Richard ||single_quote|| s night to Bolingbroke ||single_quote|| s fair day ||period|| 
So that by this intelligence we learn
The Welshmen are dispersed ||comma|| and Salisbury
Is gone to meet the king ||comma|| who lately landed
With some few private friends upon this coast ||period|| 
The news is very fair and good ||comma|| my lord:
Richard not far from hence hath hid his head ||period|| 
It would beseem the Lord Northumberland
To say ||single_quote|| King Richard: ||single_quote|| alack the heavy day
When such a sacred king should hide his head ||period|| 
Your grace mistakes ||semicolon|| only to be brief
Left I his title out ||period|| 
The time hath been ||comma|| 
Would you have been so brief with him ||comma|| he would
Have been so brief with you ||comma|| to shorten you ||comma|| 
For taking so the head ||comma|| your whole head ||single_quote|| s length ||period||

Royally ||exclamation_mark|| 
Why ||comma|| it contains no king ||question_mark|| 
Yes ||comma|| my good lord ||comma||

Noble lords ||comma|| 
Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle ||semicolon|| 
Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley
Into his ruin ||single_quote|| d ears ||comma|| and thus deliver:
Henry Bolingbroke
On both his knees doth kiss King Richard ||single_quote|| s hand
And sends allegiance and true faith of heart
To his most royal person ||comma|| hither come
Even at his feet to lay my arms and power ||comma|| 
Provided that my banishment repeal ||single_quote|| d
And lands restored again be freely granted:
If not ||comma|| I ||single_quote|| ll use the advantage of my power
And lay the summer ||single_quote|| s dust with showers of blood
Rain ||single_quote|| d from the wounds of slaughter ||single_quote|| d Englishmen:
The which ||comma|| how far off from the mind of Bolingbroke
It is ||comma|| such crimson tempest should bedrench
The fresh green lap of fair King Richard ||single_quote|| s land ||comma|| 
My stooping duty tenderly shall show ||period|| 
Go ||comma|| signify as much ||comma|| while here we march
Upon the grassy carpet of this plain ||period|| 
Let ||single_quote|| s march without the noise of threatening drum ||comma|| 
That from this castle ||single_quote|| s tatter ||single_quote|| d battlements
Our fair appointments may be well perused ||period|| 
Methinks King Richard and myself should meet
With no less terror than the elements
Of fire and water ||comma|| when their thundering shock
At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven ||period|| 
Be he the fire ||comma|| I ||single_quote|| ll be the yielding water:
The rage be his ||comma|| whilst on the earth I rain
My waters ||semicolon|| on the earth ||comma|| and not on him ||period|| 
March on ||comma|| and mark King Richard how he looks ||period|| 
See ||comma|| see ||comma|| King Richard doth himself appear ||comma|| 
As doth the blushing discontented sun
From out the fiery portal of the east ||comma|| 
When he perceives the envious clouds are bent
To dim his glory and to stain the track
Of his bright passage to the occident ||period|| 
Yet looks he like a king: behold ||comma|| his eye ||comma|| 
As bright as is the eagle ||single_quote|| s ||comma|| lightens forth
Controlling majesty: alack ||comma|| alack ||comma|| for woe ||comma|| 
That any harm should stain so fair a show ||exclamation_mark|| 
We are amazed ||semicolon|| and thus long have we stood
To watch the fearful bending of thy knee ||comma|| 
Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:
And if we be ||comma|| how dare thy joints forget
To pay their awful duty to our presence ||question_mark|| 
If we be not ||comma|| show us the hand of God
That hath dismissed us from our stewardship ||semicolon|| 
For well we know ||comma|| no hand of blood and bone
Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre ||comma|| 
Unless he do profane ||comma|| steal ||comma|| or usurp ||period|| 
And though you think that all ||comma|| as you have done ||comma|| 
Have torn their souls by turning them from us ||comma|| 
And we are barren and bereft of friends ||semicolon|| 
Yet know ||comma|| my master ||comma|| God omnipotent ||comma|| 
Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf
Armies of pestilence ||semicolon|| and they shall strike
Your children yet unborn and unbegot ||comma|| 
That lift your vassal hands against my head
And threat the glory of my precious crown ||period|| 
Tell Bolingbroke ||dash|| for yond methinks he stands ||dash|| 
That every stride he makes upon my land
Is dangerous treason: he is come to open
The purple testament of bleeding war ||semicolon|| 
But ere the crown he looks for live in peace ||comma|| 
Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers ||single_quote|| sons
Shall ill become the flower of England ||single_quote|| s face ||comma|| 
Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace
To scarlet indignation and bedew
Her pastures ||single_quote|| grass with faithful English blood ||period|| 
The king of heaven forbid our lord the king
Should so with civil and uncivil arms

Which on thy royal party granted once ||comma||

To faithful service of your majesty ||period||

LADY

Why should we in the compass of a pale

We lop away ||comma|| that bearing boughs may live:
Had he done so ||comma|| himself had borne the crown ||comma|| 
Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down ||period||

Princes and noble lords ||comma||

In this appeal as thou art all unjust ||semicolon|| 
And that thou art so ||comma|| there I throw my gage ||comma|| 
To prove it on thee to the extremest point
Of mortal breathing: seize it ||comma|| if thou darest ||period|| 
An if I do not ||comma|| may my hands rot off
And never brandish more revengeful steel

LORD
I task the earth to the like ||comma|| forsworn Aumerle ||semicolon|| 
And spur thee on with full as many lies
As may be holloa ||single_quote|| d in thy treacherous ear
From sun to sun: there is my honour ||single_quote|| s pawn ||semicolon|| 
Engage it to the trial ||comma|| if thou darest ||period|| 
Who sets me else ||question_mark|| by heaven ||comma|| I ||single_quote|| ll throw at all:
I have a thousand spirits in one breast ||comma|| 
To answer twenty thousand such as you ||period|| 
DUKE OF SURREY
My Lord Fitzwater ||comma|| I do remember well
The very time Aumerle and you did talk ||period|| 
 ||single_quote|| Tis very true: you were in presence then ||semicolon|| 
And you can witness with me this is true ||period|| 
DUKE OF SURREY
As false ||comma|| by heaven ||comma|| as heaven itself is true ||period|| 
Surrey ||comma|| thou liest ||period|| 
DUKE OF SURREY
Dishonourable boy ||exclamation_mark|| 
That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword ||comma|| 
That it shall render vengeance and revenge
Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie
In earth as quiet as thy father ||single_quote|| s skull:
In proof whereof ||comma|| there is my honour ||single_quote|| s pawn ||semicolon|| 
Engage it to the trial ||comma|| if thou darest ||period|| 
How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse ||exclamation_mark|| 
If I dare eat ||comma|| or drink ||comma|| or breathe ||comma|| or live ||comma|| 
I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness ||comma|| 
And spit upon him ||comma|| whilst I say he lies ||comma|| 
And lies ||comma|| and lies: there is my bond of faith ||comma|| 
To tie thee to my strong correction ||period|| 
As I intend to thrive in this new world ||comma|| 
Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal:
Besides ||comma|| I heard the banish ||single_quote|| d Norfolk say
That thou ||comma|| Aumerle ||comma|| didst send two of thy men
To execute the noble duke at Calais ||period|| 
Some honest Christian trust me with a gage
That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this ||comma|| 
If he may be repeal ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| to try his honour ||period|| 
These differences shall all rest under gage
Till Norfolk be repeal ||single_quote|| d: repeal ||single_quote|| d he shall be ||comma|| 
And ||comma|| though mine enemy ||comma|| restored again
To all his lands and signories: when he ||single_quote|| s return ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial ||period|| 
That honourable day shall ne ||single_quote|| er be seen ||period|| 
Many a time hath banish ||single_quote|| d Norfolk fought
For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field ||comma|| 
Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross

I have been studying how I may compare
This prison where I live unto the world:
And for because the world is populous
And here is not a creature but myself ||comma|| 
I cannot do it ||semicolon|| yet I ||single_quote|| ll hammer it out ||period||

And these same thoughts people this little world ||comma|| 
In humours like the people of this world ||comma|| 
For no thought is contented ||period|| The better sort ||comma|| 
As thoughts of things divine ||comma|| are intermix ||single_quote|| d

Against the word:
As thus ||comma|| ||single_quote|| Come ||comma|| little ones ||comma|| ||single_quote|| and then again ||comma||

Thoughts tending to ambition ||comma|| they do plot
Unlikely wonders ||semicolon|| how these vain weak nails
May tear a passage through the flinty ribs
Of this hard world ||comma|| my ragged prison walls ||comma|| 
And ||comma|| for they cannot ||comma|| die in their own pride ||period|| 
Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves
That they are not the first of fortune ||single_quote|| s slaves ||comma|| 
Nor shall not be the last ||semicolon|| like silly beggars
Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame ||comma|| 
That many have and others must sit there ||semicolon|| 
And in this thought they find a kind of ease ||comma|| 
Bearing their own misfortunes on the back
Of such as have before endured the like ||period|| 
Thus play I in one person many people ||comma|| 
And none contented: sometimes am I king ||semicolon|| 
Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar ||comma|| 
And so I am: then crushing penury
Persuades me I was better when a king ||semicolon|| 
Then am I king ||single_quote|| d again: and by and by
Think that I am unking ||single_quote|| d by Bolingbroke ||comma|| 
And straight am nothing: but whate ||single_quote|| er I be ||comma||

With nothing shall be pleased ||comma|| till he be eased
With being nothing ||period|| Music do I hear ||question_mark|| 
Ha ||comma|| ha ||exclamation_mark|| keep time: how sour sweet music is ||comma|| 
When time is broke and no proportion kept ||exclamation_mark|| 
So is it in the music of men ||single_quote|| s lives ||period||

To cheque time broke in a disorder ||single_quote|| d string ||semicolon||

I wasted time ||comma|| and now doth time waste me ||semicolon|| 
For now hath time made me his numbering clock:
My thoughts are minutes ||semicolon|| and with sighs they jar
Their watches on unto mine eyes ||comma|| the outward watch ||comma|| 
Whereto my finger ||comma|| like a dial ||single_quote|| s point ||comma|| 
Is pointing still ||comma|| in cleansing them from tears ||period|| 
Now sir ||comma|| the sound that tells what hour it is
Are clamorous groans ||comma|| which strike upon my heart ||comma||

Show minutes ||comma|| times ||comma|| and hours: but my time
Runs posting on in Bolingbroke ||single_quote|| s proud joy ||comma|| 
While I stand fooling here ||comma|| his Jack o ||single_quote|| the clock ||period||

Here were the servants of your adversary ||comma|| 
And yours ||comma|| close fighting ere I did approach:
I drew to part them: in the instant came
The fiery Tybalt ||comma|| with his sword prepared ||comma|| 
Which ||comma|| as he breathed defiance to my ears ||comma|| 
He swung about his head and cut the winds ||comma|| 
Who nothing hurt withal hiss ||single_quote|| d him in scorn:
While we were interchanging thrusts and blows ||comma|| 
Came more and more and fought on part and part ||comma|| 
Till the prince came ||comma|| who parted either part ||period||

Madam ||comma|| an hour before the worshipp ||single_quote|| d sun

Where ||comma|| underneath the grove of sycamore
That westward rooteth from the city ||single_quote|| s side ||comma|| 
So early walking did I see your son:
Towards him I made ||comma|| but he was ware of me
And stole into the covert of the wood:
I ||comma|| measuring his affections by my own ||comma|| 
That most are busied when they ||single_quote|| re most alone ||comma|| 
Pursued my humour not pursuing his ||comma|| 
And gladly shunn ||single_quote|| d who gladly fled from me ||period|| 
Many a morning hath he there been seen ||comma|| 
With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew ||period|| 
Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs ||semicolon|| 
But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
Should in the furthest east begin to draw
The shady curtains from Aurora ||single_quote|| s bed ||comma|| 
Away from the light steals home my heavy son ||comma|| 
And private in his chamber pens himself ||comma|| 
Shuts up his windows ||comma|| locks far daylight out
And makes himself an artificial night:
Black and portentous must this humour prove ||comma|| 
Unless good counsel may the cause remove ||period|| 
My noble uncle ||comma|| do you know the cause ||question_mark|| 
I neither know it nor can learn of him ||period||

Both by myself and many other friends:

Chorus
Now old desire doth in his death-bed lie ||comma|| 
And young affection gapes to be his heir ||semicolon|| 
That fair for which love groan ||single_quote|| d for and would die ||comma|| 
With tender Juliet match ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| is now not fair ||period|| 
Now Romeo is beloved and loves again ||comma||

But to his foe supposed he must complain ||comma|| 
And she steal love ||single_quote|| s sweet bait from fearful hooks:
Being held a foe ||comma|| he may not have access
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear ||semicolon|| 
And she as much in love ||comma|| her means much less

These violent delights have violent ends
And in their triumph die ||comma|| like fire and powder ||comma|| 
Which as they kiss consume: the sweetest honey
Is loathsome in his own deliciousness
And in the taste confounds the appetite:
Therefore love moderately ||semicolon|| long love doth so ||semicolon||

Come hither ||comma|| man ||period|| I see that thou art poor:

A dram of poison ||comma|| such soon-speeding gear
As will disperse itself through all the veins
That the life-weary taker may fall dead
And that the trunk may be discharged of breath
As violently as hasty powder fired
Doth hurry from the fatal cannon ||single_quote|| s womb ||period||

Why I descend into this bed of death ||comma||

But if thou ||comma|| jealous ||comma|| dost return to pry
In what I further shall intend to do ||comma|| 
By heaven ||comma|| I will tear thee joint by joint

The time and my intents are savage-wild ||comma|| 
More fierce and more inexorable far
Than empty tigers or the roaring sea ||period||

Laying MALE in the tomb
How oft when men are at the point of death
Have they been merry ||exclamation_mark|| which their keepers call
A lightning before death: O ||comma|| how may I
Call this a lightning ||question_mark|| O my love ||exclamation_mark|| my wife ||exclamation_mark||

Myself condemned and myself excused ||period||

I will be brief ||comma|| for my short date of breath
Is not so long as is a tedious tale ||period|| 
Romeo ||comma|| there dead ||comma|| was husband to that Juliet ||semicolon|| 
And she ||comma|| there dead ||comma|| that Romeo ||single_quote|| s faithful wife:

Betroth ||single_quote|| d and would have married her perforce
To County Paris: then comes she to me ||comma|| 
And ||comma|| with wild looks ||comma|| bid me devise some mean
To rid her from this second marriage ||comma|| 
Or in my cell there would she kill herself ||period|| 
Then gave I her ||comma|| so tutor ||single_quote|| d by my art ||comma|| 
A sleeping potion ||semicolon|| which so took effect
As I intended ||comma|| for it wrought on her
The form of death: meantime I writ to Romeo ||comma|| 
That he should hither come as this dire night ||comma|| 
To help to take her from her borrow ||single_quote|| d grave ||comma|| 
Being the time the potion ||single_quote|| s force should cease ||period||

Was stay ||single_quote|| d by accident ||comma|| and yesternight
Return ||single_quote|| d my letter back ||period|| Then all alone
At the prefixed hour of her waking ||comma|| 
Came I to take her from her kindred ||single_quote|| s vault ||semicolon|| 
Meaning to keep her closely at my cell ||comma|| 
Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:
But when I came ||comma|| some minute ere the time
Of her awaking ||comma|| here untimely lay
The noble Paris and true Romeo dead ||period|| 
She wakes ||semicolon|| and I entreated her come forth ||comma|| 
And bear this work of heaven with patience:
But then a noise did scare me from the tomb ||semicolon|| 
And she ||comma|| too desperate ||comma|| would not go with me ||comma|| 
But ||comma|| as it seems ||comma|| did violence on herself ||period|| 
All this I know ||semicolon|| and to the marriage
Her nurse is privy: and ||comma|| if aught in this
Miscarried by my fault ||comma|| let my old life
Be sacrificed ||comma|| some hour before his time ||comma||

Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy ||period|| 
Then take him up and manage well the jest:
Carry him gently to my fairest chamber
And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:

And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet:

Why ||comma|| I am past my gamut long ago ||period||

SERVANT
Mistress ||comma|| your father prays you leave your books
And help to dress your sister ||single_quote|| s chamber up:
You know to-morrow is the wedding-day ||period||

That Katharina and Petruchio should be married ||comma||

KATARINA
Gentlemen ||comma|| forward to the bridal dinner:
I see a woman may be made a fool ||comma|| 
If she had not a spirit to resist ||period||

And in no sense is meet or amiable ||period|| 
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled ||comma||

Thy husband is thy lord ||comma|| thy life ||comma|| thy keeper ||comma||

Should drink his blood ||comma|| mounts up to the air:

Th ||single_quote|| ambitious Mortimer would seek to curb ||comma|| 
And that unnatural queen ||comma|| false Isabel ||comma|| 
That thus hath pent and mew ||single_quote|| d me in a prison
For such outrageous passions cloy my soul ||comma|| 
As with the wings of rancour and disdain
Full oft[ten] am I soaring up to heaven ||comma|| 
To plain me to the gods against them both ||period|| 
But when I call to mind I am a king ||comma|| 
Methinks I should revenge me of my wrongs ||comma|| 
That Mortimer and Isabel have done ||period|| 
But what are kings ||comma|| when regiment is gone ||comma|| 
But perfect shadows in a sunshine day ||question_mark||

To company my heart with sad laments ||comma||
