Come gentle Ganimed and play with me ||comma|| 
I loue thee well ||comma|| say Iuno what she will ||period|| 
I am much better for your worthles loue ||comma|| 
That will not shield me from her shrewith blowes:
To day when as I fild into your cups ||comma|| 
And held the cloath of pleasance whiles you dranke ||comma|| 
She reacht me such a rap for that I spilde ||comma|| 
As made the bloud run downe about mine eares ||period|| 
What ||question_mark|| dares she strike the darling of my thoughts ||question_mark|| 
By Saturnes soule ||comma|| and this earth threatning aire ||comma|| 
That shaken thrise ||comma|| makes Natures buildings quake ||comma|| 
I vow ||comma|| if she but once frowne on thee more ||comma|| 
To hang her meteor like twixt heauen and earth ||comma|| 
And bind her hand and foote with golden cordes ||comma|| 
As once I did for harming Hercules ||period|| 
Might I but see that pretie sport a foote ||comma|| 
O how would I with Helens brother laugh ||comma|| 
And bring the Gods to wonder at the game:
Sweet Iupiter ||comma|| if ere I pleasde thine eye ||comma|| 
Or seemed faire walde in with Egles wings ||comma|| 
Grace my immortall beautie with this boone ||comma|| 
And I will spend my time in thy bright armes ||period|| 
What ist sweet wagge I should deny thy youth ||question_mark|| 
Whose face reflects such pleasure to mine eyes ||comma|| 
As I exhal ||single_quote|| d with thy fire darting beames ||comma|| 
Haue oft driuen backe the horses of the night ||period|| 
When as they would haue hal ||single_quote|| d thee from my sight:
Sit on my knee ||comma|| and call for thy content ||comma|| 
Controule proud Fate ||comma|| and cut the thred of time ||comma|| 
Why are not all the Gods at thy commaund ||comma|| 
And heauen and earth the bounds of thy delight ||question_mark|| 
Vulcan shall daunce to make thee laughing sport ||comma|| 
And my nine Daughters sing when thou art sad ||comma|| 
From Iunos bird Ile pluck her spotted pride ||comma|| 
To make thee fannes wherewith to coole thy face ||comma|| 
And Venus Swannes shall shed their siluer downe ||comma|| 
To sweeten out the slumbers of thy bed:
Hermes no more shall shew the world his wings ||comma|| 
If that thy fancie in his feathers dwell ||comma|| 
But as this one Ile teare them all from him ||comma|| 
Doe thou but say their colour pleaseth me:
Hold here my little loue these linked gems ||comma|| 
My Iuno ware vpon her marriage day ||comma|| 
Put thou about thy necke my owne sweet heart ||comma|| 
And tricke thy armes and shoulders with my theft ||period|| 
I would haue a iewell for mine eare ||comma|| 
And a fine brouch to put in my hat ||comma|| 
And then Ile hugge with you an hundred times ||period|| 
And shall haue Ganimed ||comma|| if thou wilt be my loue ||period|| 

I this is it ||comma|| you can sit toying there ||comma|| 
And playing with that female wanton boy ||comma|| 
Whiles my neas wanders on the Seas ||comma|| 
And rests a pray to euery billowes pride ||period|| 
Iuno ||comma|| false Iuno in her Chariots pompe ||comma|| 
Drawne through the heauens by Steedes of Boreas brood ||comma|| 
Made Hebe to direct her ayrie wheeles
Into the windie countrie of the clowdes ||comma|| 
Where finding olus intrencht with stormes ||comma|| 
And guarded with a thousand grislie ghosts ||comma|| 
She humbly did beseech him for our bane ||comma|| 
And charg ||single_quote|| d him drowne my sonne with all his traine ||period|| 
Then gan the windes breake ope their brazen doores ||comma|| 
And all olia to be vp in armes:
Poore Troy must now be sackt vpon the Sea ||comma|| 
And Neptunes waues be enuious men of warre ||comma|| 
Epeus horse to tnas hill transformd ||comma|| 
Prepared stands to wracke their woodden walles ||comma|| 
And olus like Agamemnon sounds
The surges ||comma|| his fierce souldiers to the spoyle:
See how the night Ulysses-like comes forth ||comma|| 
And intercepts the day as Dolon erst:
Ay me ||exclamation_mark|| the Starres supprisde like Rhesus Steedes ||comma|| 
Are drawne by darknes forth Astrus tents ||period|| 
What shall I doe to saue thee my sweet boy ||question_mark|| 
When as the waues doe threat our Chrystall world ||comma|| 
And Proteus raising hils of flouds on high ||comma|| 
Entends ere long to sport him in the skie ||period|| 
False Iupiter ||comma|| rewardst thou vertue so ||question_mark|| 
What ||question_mark|| is not pietie exempt from woe ||question_mark|| 
Then dye neas in thine innocence ||comma|| 
Since that religion hath no recompence ||period|| 
Content thee Cytherea in thy care ||comma|| 
Since thy neas wandring fate is firme ||comma|| 
Whose wearie lims shall shortly make repose ||comma|| 
In those faire walles I promist him of yore:
But first in bloud must his good fortune bud ||comma|| 
Before he be the Lord of Turnus towne ||comma|| 
Or force her smile that hetherto hath frownd:
Three winters shall he with the Rutiles warre ||comma|| 
And in the end subdue them with his sword ||comma|| 
And full three Sommers likewise shall he waste ||comma|| 
In mannaging those fierce barbarian mindes:
Which once performd ||comma|| poore Troy so long supprest ||comma|| 
From forth her ashes shall aduance her head ||comma|| 
And flourish once againe that erst was dead:
But bright Ascanius beauties better worke ||comma|| 
Who with the Sunne deuides one radiant shape ||comma|| 
Shall build his throne amidst those starrie towers ||comma|| 
That earth-borne Atlas groning vnderprops:
No bounds but heauen shall bound his Emperie ||comma|| 
Whose azured gates enchased with his name ||comma|| 
Shall make the morning halt her gray vprise ||comma|| 
To feede her eyes with his engrauen fame ||period|| 
Thus in stoute Hectors race three hundred yeares ||comma|| 
The Romane Scepter royall shall remaine ||comma|| 
Till that a Princesse priest conceau ||single_quote|| d by Mars ||comma|| 
Shall yeeld to dignitie a dubble birth ||comma|| 
Who will eternish Troy in their attempts ||period|| 
How may I credite these thy flattering termes ||comma|| 
When yet both sea and sands beset their ships ||comma|| 
And Phbus as in stygian pooles ||comma|| refraines
To taint his tresses in the Tyrrhen maine ||question_mark|| 
I will take order for that presently:
Hermes awake ||comma|| and haste to Neptunes realme ||comma|| 
Whereas the Wind-god warring now with Fate ||comma|| 
Besiege the ofspring of our kingly loynes ||comma|| 
Charge him from me to turne his stormie powers ||comma|| 
And fetter them in Vulcans sturdie brasse ||comma|| 
That durst thus proudly wrong our kinsmans peace ||period|| 
Venus farewell ||comma|| thy sonne shall be our care:
Come Ganimed ||comma|| we must about this geare ||period|| 
Disquiet Seas lay downe your swelling lookes ||comma|| 
And court neas with your calmie cheere ||comma|| 
Whose beautious burden well might make you proude ||comma|| 
Had not the heauens conceau ||single_quote|| d with hel-borne clowdes ||comma|| 
Vaild his resplendant glorie from your view ||comma|| 
For my sake pitie him Oceanus ||comma|| 
That erst-while issued from thy watrie loynes ||comma|| 
And had my being from thy bubling froth:
Triton I know hath fild his trumpe with Troy ||comma|| 
And therefore will take pitie on his toyle ||comma|| 
And call both Thetis and Cimodo ||comma|| 
To succour him in this extremitie ||period|| 

What ||question_mark|| doe I see my sonne now come on shoare:
Venus ||comma|| how art thou compast with content ||comma|| 
The while thine eyes attract their sought for ioyes:
Great Iupiter ||comma|| still honourd maist thou be ||comma|| 
For this so friendly ayde in time of neede ||period|| 
Here in this bush disguised will I stand ||comma|| 
Whiles my neas spends himselfe in plaints ||comma|| 
And heauen and earth with his vnrest acquaints ||period|| 
You sonnes of care ||comma|| companions of my course ||comma|| 
Priams misfortune followes vs by sea ||comma|| 
And Helens rape doth haunt thee at the heeles ||period|| 
How many dangers haue we ouer past ||question_mark|| 
Both barking Scilla ||comma|| and the sounding Rocks ||comma|| 
The Cyclops shelues ||comma|| and grim Ceranias seate
Haue you oregone ||comma|| and yet remaine aliue ||exclamation_mark|| 
Pluck vp your hearts ||comma|| since fate still rests our friend ||comma|| 
And chaunging heauens may those good daies returne ||comma|| 
Which Pergama did vaunt in all her pride ||period|| 
Braue Prince of Troy ||comma|| thou onely art our God ||comma|| 
That by thy vertues freest vs from annoy ||comma|| 
And makes our hopes suruiue to cunning ioyes:
Doe thou but smile ||comma|| and clowdie heauen will cleare ||comma|| 
Whose night and day descendeth from thy browes:
Though we be now in extreame miserie ||comma|| 
And rest the map of weatherbeaten woe:
Yet shall the aged Sunne shed forth his aire ||comma|| 
To make vs liue vnto our former heate ||comma|| 
And euery beast the forrest doth send forth ||comma|| 
Bequeath her young ones to our scanted foode ||period|| 
Father I faint ||comma|| good father giue me meate ||period|| 
Alas sweet boy ||comma|| thou must be still a while ||comma|| 
Till we haue fire to dresse the meate we kild:
Gentle Achates ||comma|| reach the Tinder boxe ||comma|| 
That we may make a fire to warme vs with ||comma|| 
And rost our new found victuals on this shoare ||period|| 
See what strange arts necessitie findes out ||comma|| 
How neere my sweet neas art thou driuen ||question_mark|| 
Hold ||comma|| take this candle and goe light a fire ||comma|| 
You shall haue leaues and windfall bowes enow
Neere to these woods ||comma|| to rost your meate withall:
Ascanius ||comma|| goe and drie thy drenched lims ||comma|| 
Whiles I with my Achates roaue abroad ||comma|| 
To know what coast the winde hath driuen vs on ||comma|| 
Or whether men or beasts inhabite it ||period|| 
The ayre is pleasant ||comma|| and the soyle most fit
For Cities ||comma|| and societies supports:
Yet much I maruell that I cannot finde ||comma|| 
No steps of men imprinted in the earth ||period|| 
Now is the time for me to play my part:
Hoe yong men ||comma|| saw you as you came
Any of all my Sisters wandring here ||question_mark|| 
Hauing a quiuer girded to her side ||comma|| 
And cloathed in a spotted Leopards skin ||period|| 
I neither saw nor heard of any such:
But what may I faire Virgin call your name ||question_mark|| 
Whose lookes set forth no mortall forme to view ||comma|| 
Nor speech bewraies ought humaine in thy birth ||comma|| 
Thou art a Goddesse that delud ||single_quote|| st our eyes ||comma|| 
And shrowdes thy beautie in this borrowd shape ||semicolon|| 
But whether thou the Sunnes bright Sister be ||comma|| 
Or one of chast Dianas fellow Nimphs ||comma|| 
Liue happie in the height of all content ||comma|| 
And lighten our extreames with this one boone ||comma|| 
As to instruct us vnder what good heauen
We breathe as now ||comma|| and what this world is calde ||comma|| 
On which by tempests furie we are cast ||comma|| 
Tell vs ||comma|| O tell vs that are ignorant ||comma|| 
And this right hand shall make thy Altars crack
With mountaine heapes of milke white Sacrifize ||period|| 
Such honour ||comma|| stranger ||comma|| doe I not affect:
It is the vse for Turen maides to weare
Their bowe and quiuer in this modest sort ||comma|| 
And suite themselues in purple for the nonce ||comma|| 
That they may trip more lightly ore the lawndes ||comma|| 
And ouertake the tusked Bore in chase ||period|| 
But for the land whereof thou doest enquire ||comma|| 
It is the punick kingdome rich and strong ||comma|| 
Adioyning on Agenors stately towne ||comma|| 
The kingly seate of Southerne Libia ||comma|| 
Whereas Sidonian Dido rules as Queene ||period|| 
But what are you that aske of me these things ||question_mark|| 
Whence may you come ||comma|| or whither will you goe ||question_mark|| 
Of Troy am I ||comma|| neas is my name ||comma|| 
Who driuen by warre from forth my natiue world ||comma|| 
Put sailes to sea to seeke out Italy ||semicolon|| 
And my diuine descent from sceptred Iove ||comma|| 
With twise twelue Phrigian ships I plowed the deepe ||comma|| 
And made that way my mother Venus led:
But of them all scarce seuen doe anchor safe ||comma|| 
And they so wrackt and weltred by the waues ||comma|| 
As euery tide tilts twixt their oken sides:
And all of them vnburdened of their loade ||comma|| 
Are ballassed with billowes watrie weight ||period|| 
But haples I ||comma|| God wot ||comma|| poore and vnknowne ||comma|| 
Doe trace these Libian deserts all despisde ||comma|| 
Exild forth Europe and wide Asia both ||comma|| 
And haue not any couerture but heauen ||period|| 
Fortune hath fauord thee what ere thou be ||comma|| 
In sending thee vnto this curteous Coast:
A Gods name on and hast thee to the Court ||comma|| 
Where Dido will receiue ye with her smiles:
And for thy ships which thou supposest lost ||comma|| 
Not one of them hath perisht in the storme ||comma|| 
But are ariued safe not farre from hence:
And so I leaue thee to thy fortunes lot ||comma|| 
Wishing good lucke vnto thy wandring steps ||period|| 
Achates ||comma|| tis my mother that is fled ||comma|| 
I know her by the mouings of her feete:
Stay gentle Venus ||comma|| flye not from thy sonne ||comma|| 
Too cruell ||comma|| why wilt thou forsake me thus ||question_mark|| 
Or in these shades deceiu ||single_quote|| st mine eye so oft ||question_mark|| 
Why talke we not together hand in hand ||question_mark|| 
And tell our griefes in more familiar termes:
But thou art gone and leau ||single_quote|| st me here alone ||comma|| 
To dull the ayre with my discoursiue moane ||period|| 

Follow ye Troians ||comma|| follow this braue Lord ||comma|| 
And plaine to him the summe of your distresse ||period|| 
Why ||comma|| what are you ||comma|| or wherefore doe you sewe ||question_mark|| 
Wretches of Troy ||comma|| enuied of the windes ||comma|| 
That craue such fauour at your honors feete ||comma|| 
As poore distressed miserie may pleade:
Saue ||comma|| saue ||comma|| O saue our ships from cruell fire ||comma|| 
That doe complaine the wounds of thousand waues ||comma|| 
And spare our liues whom euery spite pursues ||period|| 
We come not we to wrong your Libian Gods ||comma|| 
Or steale your houshold lares from their shrines:
Our hands are not prepar ||single_quote|| d to lawles spoyle ||comma|| 
Nor armed to offend in any kind:
Such force is farre from our vnweaponed thoughts ||comma|| 
Whose fading weale of victorie forsooke ||comma|| 
Forbids all hope to harbour neere our hearts ||period|| 
But tell me Troians ||comma|| Troians if you be ||comma|| 
Vnto what fruitfull quarters were ye bound ||comma|| 
Before that Boreas buckled with your sailes ||question_mark|| 
There is a place Hesperia term ||single_quote|| d by vs ||comma|| 
An ancient Empire ||comma|| famoused for armes ||comma|| 
And fertile in faire Ceres furrowed wealth ||comma|| 
Which now we call Italia of his name ||comma|| 
That in such peace long time did rule the same:
Thither made we ||comma|| 
When suddenly gloomie Orion rose ||comma|| 
And led our ships into the shallow sands ||comma|| 
Whereas the Southerne winde with brackish breath ||comma|| 
Disperst them all amongst the wrackfull Rockes:
From thence a fewe of vs escapt to land ||comma|| 
The rest we feare are foulded in the flouds ||period|| 
Braue men at armes ||comma|| abandon fruitles feares ||comma|| 
Since Carthage knowes to entertaine distresse ||period|| 
I but the barbarous sort doe threat our ships ||comma|| 
And will not let vs lodge vpon the sands:
In multitudes they swarme vnto the shoare ||comma|| 
And from the first earth interdict our feete ||period|| 
My selfe will see they shall not trouble ye ||comma|| 
Your men and you shall banquet in our Court ||comma|| 
And euery Troian be as welcome here ||comma|| 
As Iupiter to sillie Vausis house:
Come in with me ||comma|| Ile bring you to my Queene ||comma|| 
Who shall confirme my words with further deedes ||period|| 
Thankes gentle Lord for such vnlookt for grace ||comma|| 
Might we but once more see neas face ||comma|| 
Then would we hope to quite such friendly turnes ||comma|| 
As shall surpasse the wonder of our speech ||period|| 
Where am I now ||question_mark|| these should be Carthage walles ||period|| 
Why stands my sweete neas thus amazde ||question_mark|| 
O my Achates ||comma|| Theban Niobe ||comma|| 
Who for her sonnes death wept out life and breath ||comma|| 
And drie with griefe was turnd into a stone ||comma|| 
Had not such passions in her head as I ||period|| 
Me thinkes that towne there should be Troy ||comma|| yon Idas hill ||comma|| 
There Zanthus streame ||comma|| because here ||single_quote|| s Priamus ||comma|| 
And when I know it is not ||comma|| then I dye ||period|| 
And in this humor is Achates to ||comma|| 
I cannot choose but fall vpon my knees ||comma|| 
And kisse his hand: O where is Hecuba ||comma|| 
Here she was wont to sit ||comma|| but sauing ayre
Is nothing here ||comma|| and what is this but stone ||question_mark|| 
O yet this stone doth make neas weepe ||comma|| 
And would my prayers ||left_parentheses|| as Pigmalions did ||right_parentheses|| 
Could giue it life ||comma|| that vnder his conduct
We might saile backe to Troy and be reuengde
On these hard harted Grecians ||semicolon|| which reioyce
That nothing now is left of Priamus:
O Priamus is left and this is he ||comma|| 
Come ||comma|| come abourd ||comma|| pursue the hatefull Greekes ||period|| 
What means neas ||question_mark|| 
Achates though mine eyes say this is stone ||comma|| 
Yet thinkes my minde that this is Priamus:
And when my grieued heart sighes and sayes no ||comma|| 
Then would it leape out to giue Priam life:
O were I not at all so thou mightst be ||period|| 
Achates ||comma|| see King Priam wags his hand ||comma|| 
He is aliue ||comma|| Troy is not ouercome ||period|| 
Thy mind neas that would haue it so
Deludes thy eye sight ||comma|| Priamus is dead ||period|| 
Ah Troy is sackt ||comma|| and Priamus is dead ||comma|| 
And why should poore neas be aliue ||question_mark|| 
Sweete father leaue to weepe ||comma|| this is not he:
For were it Priam he would smile on me ||period|| 
neas see here come the Citizens ||comma|| 
Leaue to lament lest they laugh at our feares ||period|| 
Lords of this towne ||comma|| or whatsoeuer stile
Belongs vnto your name ||comma|| vouchsafe of ruth
To tell vs who inhabits this faire towne ||comma|| 
What kind of people ||comma|| and who gouernes them:
For we are strangers driuen on this shore ||comma|| 
And scarcely know within what Clime we are ||period|| 
I heare neas voyce ||comma|| but see him not ||comma|| 
For none of these can be our Generall ||period|| 
Like Illioneus speakes this Noble man ||comma|| 
But Illioneus goes not in such robes ||period|| 
You are Achates ||comma|| or I deciu ||single_quote|| d ||period|| 
neas see Sergestus or his ghost ||period|| 
He meanes neas ||comma|| let vs kisse his feete ||period|| 
It is our Captaine ||comma|| see Ascanius ||period|| 
Liue long neas and Ascanius ||period|| 
Achates ||comma|| speake ||comma|| for I am ouerioyed ||period|| 
O Illioneus ||comma|| art thou yet aliue ||question_mark|| 
Blest be the time I see Achates face ||period|| 
Why turnes neas from his trustie friends ||question_mark|| 
Sergestus ||comma|| Illioneus and the rest ||comma|| 
Your sight amazde me ||comma|| O what destinies
Haue brought my sweete companions in such plight ||question_mark|| 
O tell me ||comma|| for I long to be resolu ||single_quote|| d ||period|| 
Louely neas ||comma|| these are Carthage walles ||comma|| 
And here Queene Dido weares th ||single_quote|| imperiall Crowne ||comma|| 
Who for Troyes sake hath entertaind vs all ||comma|| 
And clad vs in these wealthie robes we weare ||period|| 
Oft hath she askt vs vnder whom we seru ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
And when we told her she would weepe for griefe ||comma|| 
Thinking the sea had swallowed vp thy ships ||comma|| 
And now she sees thee how will she reioyce ||question_mark|| 
See where her seruitors passe through the hall
Bearing a banket ||comma|| Dido is not farre ||period|| 
Looke where she comes: neas viewd her well ||period|| 
Well may I view her ||comma|| but she sees not me ||period|| 
What stranger art thou that doest eye me thus ||question_mark|| 
Sometime I was a Troian mightie Queene:
But Troy is not ||comma|| what shall I say I am ||question_mark|| 
Renowmed Dido ||comma|| tis our Generall: warlike neas ||period|| 
Warlike neas ||comma|| and in these base robes ||question_mark|| 
Goe fetch the garment which Sicheus ware:
Braue Prince ||comma|| welcome to Carthage and to me ||comma|| 
Both happie that neas is our guest:
Sit in this chaire and banquet with a Queene ||comma|| 
neas is neas ||comma|| were he clad
In weedes as bad as euer Irus ware ||period|| 
This is no seate for one thats comfortles ||comma|| 
May it please your grace to let neas waite:
For though my birth be great ||comma|| my fortunes meane ||comma|| 
Too meane to be companion to a Queene ||period|| 
Thy fortune may be greater then thy birth ||comma|| 
Sit downe neas ||comma|| sit in place ||comma|| 
And if this be thy sonne as I suppose ||comma|| 
Here let him sit ||comma|| be merrie louely child ||period|| 
This place beseemes me not ||comma|| O pardon me ||period|| 
Ile haue it so ||comma|| neas be content ||period|| 
Madame ||comma|| you shall be my mother ||period|| 
And so I will sweete child: be merrie man ||comma|| 
Heres to thy better fortune and good starres ||period|| 
In all humilitie I thanke your grace ||period|| 
Remember who thou art ||comma|| speake like thy selfe ||comma|| 
Humilitie belongs to common groomes ||period|| 
And who so miserable as neas is ||question_mark|| 
Lyes it in hands to make thee blest ||comma|| 
Then be assured thou art not miserable ||period|| 
O Priamus ||comma|| O Troy ||comma|| oh Hecuba ||exclamation_mark|| 
May I entreate thee to discourse at large ||comma|| 
And truely to how Troy was ouercome:
For many tales goe of that Cities fall ||comma|| 
And scarcely doe agree vpon one poynt:
Some say Antenor did betray the towne ||comma|| 
Others report twas Sinons periurie:
But all in this that Troy is ouercome ||comma|| 
And Priam dead ||comma|| yet how we heare no newes ||period|| 
A wofull tale bids Dido to vnfould ||comma|| 
Whose memorie like pale deaths stony mace ||comma|| 
Beates forth my senses from this troubled soule ||comma|| 
And makes neas sinke at feete ||period|| 
What faints neas to remember Troy ||question_mark|| 
In whose defence he fought so valiantly:
Looke vp and speake ||period|| 
Then speake neas with Achilles tongue ||comma|| 
And Dido and you Carthaginian Peeres
Heare me ||comma|| but yet with Mirmidons harsh eares ||comma|| 
Daily inur ||single_quote|| d to broyles and Massacres ||comma|| 
Lest you be mou ||single_quote|| d too much with my sad tale ||period|| 
The Grecian souldiers tired with ten yeares warre ||semicolon|| 
Began to crye ||comma|| let vs vnto our ships ||comma|| 
Troy is inuincible ||comma|| why stay we here ||question_mark|| 
With whose outcryes Atrides being apal ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
Summoned the Captaines to his princely tent ||comma|| 
Who looking on the scarres we Troians gaue ||comma|| 
Seeing the number of their men decreast ||comma|| 
And the remainder weake and out of heart ||comma|| 
Gaue vp their voyces to dislodge the Campe ||comma|| 
And so in troopes all marcht to Tenedos:
Where when they came ||comma|| Vlysses on the sand
Assayd with honey words to turne them backe:
And as he spoke to further his entent ||comma|| 
The windes did driue huge billowes to the shoare ||comma|| 
And heauen was darkned with tempestuous clowdes:
Then he alleag ||single_quote|| d the Gods would haue them stay ||comma|| 
And prophecied Troy should be ouercome:
And therewithall he calde false Sinon forth ||comma|| 
A man compact of craft and periurie ||comma|| 
Whose ticing tongue was made of Hermes pipe ||comma|| 
To force an hundred watchfull eyes to sleepe:
And him Epeus hauing made the horse ||comma|| 
With sacrificing wreathes vpon his head ||comma|| 
Vlysses sent to our vnhappie towne:
Who groueling in the mire of Zanthus bankes ||comma|| 
His hands bound at his back ||comma|| and both his eyes
Turnd vp to heauen as one resolu ||single_quote|| d to dye ||comma|| 
Our Phrigian shepherd haled within the gates ||comma|| 
And brought vnto the Court of Priamus:
To whom he vsed action so pitifull ||comma|| 
Lookes so remorcefull ||comma|| vowes so forcible ||comma|| 
As therewithall the old man ouercome ||comma|| 
Kist him ||comma|| imbrast him ||comma|| and vnloosde his bands ||comma|| 
And then ||comma|| O Dido pardon me ||period|| 
Nay leaue not here ||comma|| resolue me of the rest ||period|| 
O th ||single_quote|| inchaunting words of that base slaue ||comma|| 
Made him to thinke Epeus pine-tree Horse
A sacrifize t ||single_quote|| appease Mineruas wrath:
The rather for that one Laocoon
Breaking a speare vpon his hollow breast ||comma|| 
Was with two winged Serpents stung to death ||period|| 
Whereat agast ||comma|| we were commanded straight
With reuerence to draw it into Troy ||period|| 
In which vnhappie worke was I employd ||comma|| 
These hands did helpe to hale it to the gates ||comma|| 
Through which it could not enter twas so huge ||period|| 
O had it neuer entred ||comma|| Troy had stood ||period|| 
But Priamus impatient of delay ||comma|| 
Inforst a wide breach in that rampierd wall ||comma|| 
Which thousand battering Rams could neuer pierce ||comma|| 
And so came in this fatall instrument:
At whose accursed feete as ouerioyed ||comma|| 
We banquetted till ouercome with wine ||comma|| 
Some surfetted ||comma|| and others soundly slept ||period|| 
Which Sinon viewing ||comma|| causde the Greekish spyes
To hast to Tenedos and tell the Campe:
Then he vnlockt the Horse ||comma|| and suddenly
From out his entrailes ||comma|| Neoptolemus
Setting his speare vpon the ground ||comma|| leapt forth ||comma|| 
And after him a thousand Grecians more ||comma|| 
In whose sterne faces shin ||single_quote|| d the quenchles fire ||comma|| 
That after burnt the pride of Asia ||period|| 
By this the Campe was come vnto the walles ||comma|| 
And through the breach did march into the streetes ||comma|| 
Where meeting with the rest ||comma|| kill kill they cryed ||period|| 
Frighted with this confused noyse ||comma|| I rose ||comma|| 
And looking from a turret ||comma|| might behold
Yong infants swimming in their parents bloud ||comma|| 
Headles carkasses piled vp in heapes ||comma|| 
Virgins halfe dead dragged by their golden haire ||comma|| 
And with maine force flung on a ring of pikes ||comma|| 
Old men with swords thrust through their aged sides ||comma|| 
Kneeling for mercie to a Greekish lad ||comma|| 
Who with steele Pol-axes dasht out their braines ||period|| 
Then buckled I mine armour ||comma|| drew my sword ||comma|| 
And thinking to goe downe ||comma|| came Hectors ghost
With ashie visage ||comma|| blewish ||comma|| sulphure eyes ||comma|| 
His armes torne from his shoulders ||comma|| and his breast
Furrowd with wounds ||comma|| and that which made me weepe ||comma|| 
Thongs at his heeles ||comma|| by which Achilles horse
Drew him in triumph through the Greekish Campe ||comma|| 
Burst from the earth ||comma|| crying ||comma|| neas flye ||comma|| 
Troy is a fire ||comma|| the Grecians haue the towne ||comma|| 
O Hector who weepes not to heare thy name ||question_mark|| 
Yet flung I forth ||comma|| and desperate of my life ||comma|| 
Ran in the thickest throngs ||comma|| and with this sword
Sent many of their sauadge ghosts to hell ||period|| 
At last came Pirrhus fell and full of ire ||period|| 
His harnesse dropping bloud ||comma|| and on his speare
The mangled head of Priams yongest sonne ||comma|| 
And after him his band of Mirmidons ||comma|| 
With balles of wilde fire in their murdering pawes ||comma|| 
Which made the funerall flame that burnt faire Troy:
All which hemd me about ||comma|| crying ||comma|| this is he ||period|| 
Ah ||comma|| how could poore neas scape their hands ||question_mark|| 
My mother Venus iealous of my health ||comma|| 
Conuaid me from their crooked nets and bands:
So I escapt the furious Pirrhus wrath:
Who then ran to the pallace of the King ||comma|| 
And at Ioues Altar finding Priamus ||comma|| 
About whose withered necke hung Hecuba ||comma|| 
Foulding his hand in hers ||comma|| and ioyntly both
Beating their breasts and falling on the ground ||comma|| 
He with his faulchions poynt raisde vp at once ||comma|| 
And with Megeras eyes stared in their face ||comma|| 
Threatning a thousand deaths at euery glaunce ||period|| 
To whom the aged King thus trembling spoke:
Achilles sonne ||comma|| remember what I was ||comma|| 
Father of fiftie sonnes ||comma|| but they are slaine ||comma|| 
Lord of my fortune ||comma|| but my fortunes turnd ||comma|| 
King of this Citie ||comma|| but my Troy is fired ||comma|| 
And now am neither father ||comma|| Lord ||comma|| nor King:
Yet who so wretched but desires to liue ||question_mark|| 
O let me liue ||comma|| great Neoptolemus ||comma|| 
Not mou ||single_quote|| d at all ||comma|| but smiling at his teares ||comma|| 
This butcher whil ||single_quote|| st his hands were yet held vp ||comma|| 
Treading vpon his breast ||comma|| strooke off his hands ||period|| 
O end neas ||comma|| I can heare no more ||period|| 
At which the franticke Queene leapt on his face ||comma|| 
And in his eyelids hanging by the nayles ||comma|| 
A little while prolong ||single_quote|| d her husbands life:
At last the souldiers puld her by the heeles ||comma|| 
And swong her howling in the emptie ayre ||comma|| 
Which sent an eccho to the wounded King:
Whereat he lifted vp his bedred lims ||comma|| 
And would haue grappeld with Achilles sonne ||comma|| 
Forgetting both his want of strength and hands ||comma|| 
Which he disdaining whiskt his sword about ||comma|| 
And with the wound thereof the King fell downe:
Then from the nauell to the throat at once ||comma|| 
He ript old Priam: at whose latter gaspe
Ioues marble statue gan to bend the brow ||comma|| 
As lothing Pirrhus for this wicked act:
Yet he vndaunted tooke his fathers flagge ||comma|| 
And dipt it in the old Kings chill cold bloud ||comma|| 
And then in triumph ran into the streetes ||comma|| 
Through which he could not passe for slaughtred men:
So leaning on his sword he stood stone still ||comma|| 
Viewing the fire wherewith rich Ilion burnt ||period|| 
By this I got my father on my backe ||comma|| 
This yong boy in mine armes ||comma|| and by the hand
Led faire Creusa my beloued wife ||comma|| 
When thou Achates with thy sword mad ||single_quote|| st way ||comma|| 
And we were round inuiron ||single_quote|| d with the Greekes:
O there I lost my wife: and had not we
Fought manfully ||comma|| I had not told this tale:
Yet manhood would not serue ||comma|| of force we fled ||comma|| 
And as we went vnto our ships ||comma|| thou knowest
We sawe Cassandra sprauling in the streetes ||comma|| 
Whom Aiax rauisht in Dianas Fawne ||comma|| 
Her cheekes swolne with sighes ||comma|| her haire all rent ||comma|| 
Whom I tooke vp to beare vnto our ships ||semicolon|| 
But suddenly the Grecians followed vs ||comma|| 
And I alas ||comma|| was forst to let her lye ||period|| 
Then got we to our ships ||comma|| and being abourd ||comma|| 
Polixena cryed out ||comma|| neas stay ||comma|| 
The Greekes pursue me ||comma|| stay and take me in ||period|| 
Moued with her voyce ||comma|| I lept into the sea ||comma|| 
Thinking to beare her on my backe abourd:
For all our ships were launcht into the deepe ||comma|| 
And as I swomme ||comma|| she standing on the shoare ||comma|| 
Was by the cruell Mirmidons surprizd ||comma|| 
And after by that Pirrhus sacrifizde ||period|| 
I dye with melting ruth ||comma|| neas leaue ||period|| 
O what became of aged Hecuba ||question_mark|| 
How got neas to the fleete againe ||question_mark|| 
But how scapt Helen ||comma|| she that causde this warre ||question_mark|| 
Achates speake ||comma|| sorrow hath tired me quite ||period|| 
What happened to the Queene we cannot shewe ||comma|| 
We heare they led her captiue into Greece ||comma|| 
As for neas he swomme quickly backe ||comma|| 
And Helena betraied Diiphobus
Her Louer ||comma|| after Alexander dyed ||comma|| 
And so was reconcil ||single_quote|| d to Menelaus ||period|| 
O had that ticing strumpet nere been borne:
Troian ||comma|| thy ruthfull tale hath made me sad:
Come let vs thinke vpon some pleasing sport ||comma|| 
To rid me from these melancholly thoughts ||period|| 
Faire child stay thou with waiting maide ||comma|| 
Ile giue thee Sugar-almonds ||comma|| sweete Conserues ||comma|| 
A siluer girdle ||comma|| and a golden purse ||comma|| 
And this yong Prince shall be thy playfellow ||period|| 
Are you Queene sonne ||question_mark|| 
I ||comma|| and my mother gaue me this fine bow ||period|| 
Shall I haue such a quiuer and a bow ||question_mark|| 
Such bow ||comma|| such quiuer ||comma|| and such golden shafts ||comma|| 
Will Dido giue to sweete Ascanius:
For sake I take thee in my armes ||comma|| 
And sticke these spangled feathers in thy hat ||comma|| 
Eate Comfites in mine armes ||comma|| and I will sing ||period|| 
Now is he fast asleepe ||comma|| and in this groue
Amongst greene brakes Ile lay Ascanius ||comma|| 
And strewe him with sweete smelling Violets ||comma|| 
Blushing Roses ||comma|| purple Hyacinthe:
These milke white Doues shall be his Centronels:
Who if that any seeke to doe him hurt ||comma|| 
Will quickly flye to Citheidas fist ||period|| 
Now Cupid turne thee to Ascanius shape ||comma|| 
And goe to Dido who in stead of him
Will set thee on her lap and play with thee:
Then touch her white breast with this arrow head ||comma|| 
That she may dote vpon neas loue:
And by that meanes repaire his broken ships ||comma|| 
Victuall his Souldiers ||comma|| giue him wealthie gifts ||comma|| 
And he at last depart to Italy ||comma|| 
Or els in Carthage make his kingly throne ||period|| 
I will faire mother ||comma|| and so play my part ||comma|| 
As euery touch shall wound Queene heart ||period|| 
Sleepe my sweete nephew in these cooling shades ||comma|| 
Free from the murmure of these running streames ||comma|| 
The crye of beasts ||comma|| the ratling of the windes ||comma|| 
Or whisking of these leaues ||comma|| all shall be still ||comma|| 
And nothing interrupt thy quiet sleepe ||comma|| 
Till I returne and take thee hence againe ||period|| 

Now Cupid cause the Carthaginian Queene ||comma|| 
To be inamourd of thy brothers lookes ||comma|| 
Conuey this golden arrowe in thy sleeue ||comma|| 
Lest she imagine thou art Venus sonne:
And when she strokes thee softly on the head ||comma|| 
Then shall I touch her breast and conquer her ||period|| 
How long faire Dido shall I pine for thee ||question_mark|| 
Tis not enough that thou doest graunt me loue ||comma|| 
But that I may enioy what I desire:
That loue is childish which consists in words ||period|| 
Iarbus ||comma|| know that thou of all my wooers
 ||left_parentheses|| And yet haue I had many mightier Kings ||right_parentheses|| 
Hast had the greatest fauours I could giue:
I feare me Dido hath been counted light ||comma|| 
In being too familiar with Iarbus:
Albeit the Gods doe know no wanton thought
Had euer residence in breast ||period|| 
But Dido is the fauour I request ||period|| 
Feare not Iarbus ||comma|| Dido may be thine ||period|| 
Looke sister how neas little sonne
Playes with your garments and imbraceth you ||period|| 
No Dido will not take me in her armes ||comma|| 
I shall not be her sonne ||comma|| she loues me not ||period|| 
Weepe not sweet boy ||comma|| thou shalt be sonne ||comma|| 
Sit in my lap and let me heare thee sing ||period|| 
No more my child ||comma|| now talke another while ||comma|| 
And tell me where learnst thou this pretie song ||question_mark|| 
My cosin Helen taught it me in Troy ||period|| 
How louely is Ascanius when he smiles ||question_mark|| 
Will Dido let me hang about her necke ||question_mark|| 
I wagge ||comma|| and giue thee leaue to kisse her to ||period|| 
What will you giue me ||question_mark|| now Ile haue this Fanne ||period|| 
Take it Ascanius ||comma|| for thy fathers sake ||period|| 
Come Dido ||comma|| leaue Ascanius ||comma|| let vs walke ||period|| 
Goe thou away ||comma|| Ascanius shall stay ||period|| 
Vngentle Queene ||comma|| is this thy loue to me ||question_mark|| 
O stay Iarbus ||comma|| and Ile goe with thee ||period|| 
And if my mother goe ||comma|| Ile follow her ||period|| 
Why staiest thou here ||question_mark|| thou art no loue of mine ||question_mark|| 
Iarbus dye ||comma|| seeing she abandons thee ||period|| 
No ||comma|| liue Iarbus ||comma|| what hast thou deseru ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
That I should say thou art no loue of mine ||question_mark|| 
Something thou hast deseru ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| away I say ||comma|| 
Depart from Carthage ||comma|| come not in my sight ||period|| 
Am I not King of rich Getulia ||question_mark|| 
Iarbus pardon me ||comma|| and stay a while ||period|| 
Mother ||comma|| looke here ||period|| 
What telst thou me of rich Getulia ||question_mark|| 
Am not I Queene of Libia ||question_mark|| then depart ||period|| 
I goe to feed the humour of my Loue ||comma|| 
Yet not from Carthage for a thousand worlds ||period|| 
Iarbus ||period|| 
Doth Dido call me backe ||question_mark|| 
No ||comma|| but I charge thee neuer looke on me ||period|| 
Then pull out both mine eyes ||comma|| or let me dye ||period|| 
Wherefore doth Dido bid Iarbus goe ||question_mark|| 
Because his lothsome sight offends mine eye ||comma|| 
And in my thoughts is shrin ||single_quote|| d another loue:
O Anna ||comma|| didst thou know how sweet loue were ||comma|| 
Full soone wouldst thou abiure this single life ||period|| 
Poore soule I know too well the sower of loue ||comma|| 
O that Iarbus could but fancie me ||period|| 
Is not neas faire and beautifull ||question_mark|| 
Yes ||comma|| and Iarbus foule and fauourles ||period|| 
Is he not eloquent in all his speech ||question_mark|| 
Yes ||comma|| and Iarbus rude and rusticall ||period|| 
Name not Iarbus ||comma|| but sweete Anna say ||comma|| 
Is not neas worthie loue ||question_mark|| 
O sister ||comma|| were you Empresse of the world ||comma|| 
neas well deserues to be your loue ||comma|| 
So lovely is he that where ere he goes ||comma|| 
The people swarme to gaze him in the face ||period|| 
But tell them none shall gaze on him but I ||comma|| 
Lest their grosse eye-beames taint my louers cheekes:
Anna ||comma|| good sister Anna goe for him ||comma|| 
Lest with these sweete thoughts I melt cleane away ||period|| 
Then sister youle abiure Iarbus loue ||question_mark|| 
Yet must I heare that lothsome name againe ||question_mark|| 
Runne for neas ||comma|| or Ile flye to him ||period|| 
You shall not hurt my father when he comes ||period|| 
No ||comma|| for thy sake Ile loue thy father well ||period|| 
O dull conceipted Dido ||comma|| that till now
Didst neuer thinke neas beautifull:
But now for quittance of this ouersight ||comma|| 
Ile make me bracelets of his golden haire ||comma|| 
His glistering eyes shall be my looking glasse ||comma|| 
His lips an altar ||comma|| where Ile offer vp
As many kisses as the Sea hath sands ||comma|| 
In stead of musicke I will heare him speake ||comma|| 
His lookes shall be my only Librarie ||comma|| 
And thou neas ||comma|| Didos treasurie ||comma|| 
In whose faire bosome I will locke more wealth ||comma|| 
Then twentie thousand Indiaes can affoord:
O here he comes ||comma|| loue ||comma|| loue ||comma|| giue Dido leaue
To be more modest then her thoughts admit ||comma|| 
Lest I be made a wonder to the world ||period|| 
Achates ||comma|| how doth Carthage please your Lord ||question_mark|| 
That will neas shewe your maiestie ||period|| 
neas art thou there ||question_mark|| 
I vnderstand your highnesse sent for me ||period|| 
No ||comma|| but now thou art here ||comma|| tell me in sooth ||comma|| 
In what might Dido highly pleasure thee ||period|| 
So much haue I receiu ||single_quote|| d at hands ||comma|| 
As without blushing I can aske no more:
Yet Queene of Affricke ||comma|| are my ships vnrigd ||comma|| 
My Sailes all rent in sunder with the winde ||comma|| 
My Oares broken ||comma|| and my Tackling lost ||comma|| 
Yea all my Nauie split with Rockes and Shelfes:
Nor Sterne nor Anchor haue our maimed Fleete ||comma|| 
Our Masts the furious windes strooke ouer bourd:
Which piteous wants if Dido will supplie ||comma|| 
We will account her author of our liues ||period|| 
 neas ||comma|| Ile repaire thy Troian ships ||comma|| 
Conditionally that thou wilt stay with me ||comma|| 
And let Achates saile to Italy:
Ile giue thee tackling made of riueld gold ||comma|| 
Wound on the barkes of odoriferous trees ||comma|| 
Oares of massie Iuorie full of holes ||comma|| 
Through which the water shall delight to play:
Thy Anchors shall be hewed from Christall Rockes ||comma|| 
Which if thou lose shall shine aboue the waues ||semicolon|| 
The Masts whereon thy swelling sailes shall hang ||comma|| 
Hollow Pyramides of siluer plate:
The sailes of foulded Lawne ||comma|| where shall be wrought
The warres of Troy ||comma|| but not Troyes ouerthrow:
For ballace ||comma|| emptie treasurie ||comma|| 
Take what ye will ||comma|| but leaue neas here ||period|| 
Achates ||comma|| thou shalt be so meanly clad ||comma|| 
As Seaborne Nymphes shall swarme about thy ships ||comma|| 
And wanton Mermaides court thee with sweete songs ||comma|| 
Flinging in fauours of more soueraigne worth ||comma|| 
Then Thetis hangs about Apolloes necke ||comma|| 
So that neas may but stay with me ||period|| 
Wherefore would Dido haue neas stay ||question_mark|| 
To warre against my bordering enemies:
neas ||comma|| thinke not Dido is in loue:
For if that any man could conquer me ||comma|| 
I had been wedded ere neas came:
See where the pictures of my suiters hang ||comma|| 
And are not these as faire as faire may be ||question_mark|| 
I saw this man at Troy ere Troy was sackt ||period|| 
I this in Greece when Paris stole faire Helen ||period|| 
This man and I were at Olympus games ||period|| 
I know this face ||comma|| he is a Persian borne ||comma|| 
I traueld with him to tolia ||period|| 
And I in Athens with this gentleman ||comma|| 
Vnlesse I be deceiu ||single_quote|| d disputed once ||period|| 
But speake neas ||comma|| know you none of these ||question_mark|| 
No Madame ||comma|| but it seemes that these are Kings ||period|| 
All these and others which I neuer sawe ||comma|| 
Haue been most vrgent suiters for my loue ||comma|| 
Some came in person ||comma|| others sent their Legats:
Yet none obtaind me ||comma|| I am free from all ||comma|| 
And yet God knowes intangled vnto one ||period|| 
This was an Orator ||comma|| and thought by words
To compasse me ||comma|| but yet he was deceiu ||single_quote|| d:
And this a Spartan Courtier vaine and wilde ||comma|| 
But his fantastick humours pleasde not me:
This was Alcion ||comma|| a Musition ||comma|| 
But playd he nere so sweet ||comma|| I let him goe:
This was the wealthie King of Thessaly ||comma|| 
But I had gold enough and cast him off:
This Meleagers sonne ||comma|| a warlike Prince ||comma|| 
But weapons gree not with my tender yeares:
The rest are such as all the world well knowes ||comma|| 
Yet how I sweare by heauen and him I loue ||comma|| 
I was as farre from loue ||comma|| as they from hate ||period|| 
O happie shall he be whom Dido loues ||period|| 
Then neuer say that thou art miserable ||comma|| 
Because it may be thou shalt be my loue:
Yet boast not of it ||comma|| for I loue thee not ||comma|| 
And yet I hate thee not: O if I speake
I shall betray my selfe: neas speake ||comma|| 
We two will goe a hunting in the woods ||comma|| 
But not so much for thee ||comma|| thou art but one ||comma|| 
As for Achates ||comma|| and his followers ||period|| 
Here lyes my hate ||comma|| neas cursed brat ||comma|| 
The boy wherein false destinie delights ||comma|| 
The heire of furie ||comma|| the fauorite of the face ||comma|| 
That vgly impe that shall outweare my wrath ||comma|| 
And wrong my deitie with high disgrace:
But I will take another order now ||comma|| 
And race th ||single_quote|| eternall Register of time:
Troy shall no more call him her second hope ||comma|| 
Nor Venus triumph in his tender youth:
For here in spight of heauen Ile murder him ||comma|| 
And feede infection with his left out life:
Say Paris ||comma|| now shall Venus haue the ball ||question_mark|| 
Say vengeance ||comma|| now shall her Ascanius dye ||period|| 
O no God wot ||comma|| I cannot watch my time ||comma|| 
Nor quit good turnes with double fee downe told:
Tut ||comma|| I am simple without made to hurt ||comma|| 
And haue no gall at all to grieue my foes:
But lustfull Ioue and his adulterous child ||comma|| 
Shall finde it written on confusions front ||comma|| 
That onely Iuno rules in Rhamnuse towne ||period|| 
What should this meane ||question_mark|| my Doues are back returnd ||comma|| 
Who warne me of such daunger prest at hand ||comma|| 
To harme my sweete Ascanius louely life ||period|| 
Iuno ||comma|| my mortall foe ||comma|| what make you here ||question_mark|| 
Auaunt old witch and trouble not my wits ||period|| 
Fie Venus ||comma|| that such causeles words of wrath ||comma|| 
Should ere defile so faire a mouth as thine:
Are not we both sprong of celestiall rase ||comma|| 
And banquet as two Sisters with the Gods ||question_mark|| 
Why is it then displeasure should disioyne ||comma|| 
Whom kindred and acquaintance counites ||period|| 
Out hatefull hag ||comma|| thou wouldst haue slaine my sonne ||comma|| 
Had not my Doues discou ||single_quote|| rd thy entent:
But I will teare thy eyes fro forth thy head ||comma|| 
And feast the birds with their bloud-shotten balles ||comma|| 
If thou but lay thy fingers on my boy ||period|| 
Is this then all the thankes that I shall haue ||comma|| 
For sauing him from Snakes and Serpents stings ||comma|| 
That would haue kild him sleeping as he lay ||question_mark|| 
What though I was offended with thy sonne ||comma|| 
And wrought him mickle woe on sea and land ||comma|| 
When for the hate of Troian Ganimed ||comma|| 
That was aduanced by my Hebes shame ||comma|| 
And Paris iudgement of the heauenly ball ||comma|| 
I mustred all the windes vnto his wracke ||comma|| 
And vrg ||single_quote|| d each Element to his annoy:
Yet now I doe repent me of his ruth ||comma|| 
And wish that I had neuer wrongd him so:
Bootles I sawe it was to warre with fate ||comma|| 
That hath so many vnresisted friends:
Wherefore I chaunge my counsell with the time ||comma|| 
And planted loue where enuie erst had sprong ||period|| 
Sister of Ioue ||comma|| if that thy loue be such ||comma|| 
As these thy protestations doe paint forth ||comma|| 
We two as friends one fortune will deuide:
Cupid shall lay his arrowes in thy lap ||comma|| 
And to a Scepter chaunge his golden shafts ||comma|| 
Fancie and modestie shall liue as mates ||comma|| 
And thy faire peacockes by my pigeons pearch:
Loue my neas ||comma|| and desire is thine ||comma|| 
The day ||comma|| the night ||comma|| my Swannes ||comma|| my sweetes are thine ||period|| 
More then melodious are these words to me ||comma|| 
That ouercioy my soule with their content:
Venus ||comma|| sweete Venus ||comma|| how may I deserue
Such amourous fauours at thy beautious hand ||question_mark|| 
But that thou maist more easilie perceiue ||comma|| 
How highly I doe prize this amitie ||comma|| 
Harke to a motion of eternall league ||comma|| 
Which I will make in quittance of thy loue:
Thy sonne thou knowest with Dido now remaines ||comma|| 
And feedes his eyes with fauours of her Court ||comma|| 
She likewise in admyring spends her time ||comma|| 
And cannot talke nor thinke of ought but him:
Why should not they then ioyne in marriage ||comma|| 
And bring forth mightie Kings to Carthage towne ||comma|| 
Whom casualtie of sea hath made such friends ||question_mark|| 
And Venus ||comma|| let there be a match confirmd
Betwixt these two ||comma|| whose loues are so alike ||comma|| 
And both our Deities conioynd in one ||comma|| 
Shall chaine felicitie vnto their throne ||period|| 
Well could I like this reconcilements meanes ||comma|| 
But much I feare my sonne will nere consent ||comma|| 
Whose armed soule alreadie on the sea ||comma|| 
Darts forth her light to Lauinias shoare ||period|| 
Faire Queene of loue ||comma|| I will deuorce these doubts ||comma|| 
And finde the way to wearie such fond thoughts:
This day they both a hunting forth will ride
Into these woods ||comma|| adioyning to these walles ||comma|| 
When in the midst of all their gamesome sports ||comma|| 
Ile make the Clowdes dissolue their watrie workes ||comma|| 
And drench Siluanus dwellings with their shewers ||comma|| 
Then in one Caue the Queene and he shall meete ||comma|| 
And interchangeably discourse their thoughts ||comma|| 
Whose short conclusion will seale vp their hearts ||comma|| 
Vnto the purpose which we now propound ||period|| 
Sister ||comma|| I see you sauour of my wiles ||comma|| 
Be it as you will haue for this once ||comma|| 
Meane time ||comma|| Ascanius shall be my charge ||comma|| 
Whom I will beare to Ida in mine armes ||comma|| 
And couch him in Adonis purple downe ||comma|| 
neas ||comma|| thinke not but I honor thee ||comma|| 
That thus in person goe with thee to hunt:
My princely robes thou seest are layd aside ||comma|| 
Whose glittering pompe Dianas shrowdes supplies ||comma|| 
All fellowes now disposde alike to sporte ||comma|| 
The woods are wide ||comma|| and we haue store of game:
Faire Troian ||comma|| hold my golden bowe awhile ||comma|| 
Vntill I gird my quiuer to my side:
Lords goe before ||comma|| we two must talke alone ||period|| 
Vngentle ||comma|| can she wrong Iarbus so ||question_mark|| 
Ile dye before a stranger haue that grace:
We two will talke alone ||comma|| what words be these ||question_mark|| 
What makes Iarbus here of all the rest ||question_mark|| 
We could haue gone without your companie ||period|| 
But loue and duetie led him on perhaps ||comma|| 
To presse beyond acceptance to your sight ||period|| 
Why man of Troy ||comma|| doe I offend thine eyes ||question_mark|| 
Or art thou grieude thy betters presse so nye ||question_mark|| 
How now Getulian ||comma|| are ye growne so braue ||comma|| 
To challenge vs with your comparisons ||question_mark|| 
Pesant ||comma|| goe seeke companions like thy selfe ||comma|| 
And meddle not with any that I loue:
neas ||comma|| be not moude at what he sayes ||comma|| 
For otherwhile he will be out of ioynt ||period|| 
Women may wrong by priuiledge of loue:
But should that man of men ||left_parentheses|| Dido except ||right_parentheses|| 
Haue taunted me in these opprobrious termes ||comma|| 
I would haue either drunke his dying bloud ||comma|| 
Or els I would haue giuen my life in gage ||question_mark|| 
Huntsmen ||comma|| why pitch you not your toyles apace ||comma|| 
And rowse the light foote Deere from forth their laire ||period|| 
Sister ||comma|| see see Ascanius in his pompe ||comma|| 
Bearing his huntspeare brauely in his hand ||period|| 
Yea little sonne ||comma|| are you so forward now ||question_mark|| 
I mother ||comma|| I shall one day be a man ||comma|| 
And better able vnto other armes ||comma|| 
Meane time these wanton weapons serue my warre ||comma|| 
Which I will breake betwixt a Lyons iawes ||period|| 
What ||comma|| darest thou looke a Lyon in the face ||question_mark|| 
I ||comma|| and outface him to ||comma|| doe what he can ||period|| 
How like his father speaketh he in all ||question_mark|| 
And mought I liue to see him sacke rich Thebes ||comma|| 
And loade his speare with Grecian Princes heads ||comma|| 
Then would I wish me with Anchises Tombe ||comma|| 
And dead to honour that hath brought me vp ||period|| 
And might I liue to see thee shipt away ||comma|| 
And hoyst aloft on Neptunes hideous hilles ||comma|| 
Then would I wish me in faire armes ||comma|| 
And dead to scorne that hath pursued me so ||period|| 
Stoute friend Achates ||comma|| doest thou know this wood ||question_mark|| 
As I remember ||comma|| here you shot the Deere ||comma|| 
That sau ||single_quote|| d your famisht souldiers liues from death ||comma|| 
When first you set your foote vpon the shoare ||comma|| 
And here we met fair Venus virgine like ||comma|| 
Bearing her bowe and quiuer at her backe ||period|| 
O how these irksome labours now delight ||comma|| 
And ouerioy my thoughts with their escape:
Who would not vndergoe all kind of toyle ||comma|| 
To be well stor ||single_quote|| d with such a winters tale ||question_mark|| 
neas ||comma|| leaue these dumpes and lets away ||comma|| 
Some to the mountaines ||comma|| some vnto the soyle ||comma|| 
You to the vallies ||comma|| thou vnto the house ||period|| 
I ||comma|| this it is which wounds me to the death ||comma|| 
To see a Phrigian far fet to the sea ||comma|| 
Preferd before a man of maiestie:
O loue ||comma|| O hate ||comma|| O cruell womens hearts ||comma|| 
That imitate the Moone in euery chaunge ||comma|| 
And like the Planets euer loue to raunge:
What shall I doe thus wronged with disdaine ||question_mark|| 
Reuenge me on neas ||comma|| or on her:
On her ||question_mark|| fond man ||comma|| that were to warre gainst heauen ||comma|| 
And with one shaft prouoke ten thousand darts:
This Troians end will be thy enuies aime ||comma|| 
Whose bloud will reconcile thee to content ||comma|| 
And make loue drunken with thy sweete desire:
But Dido that now holdeth him so deare ||comma|| 
Will dye with very tidings of his death:
But time will discontinue her content ||comma|| 
And mould her minde vnto newe fancies shapes:
O God of heauen ||comma|| turne the hand of fate
Vnto that happie day of my delight ||comma|| 
And then ||comma|| what then ||question_mark|| Iarbus shall but loue:
So doth he now ||comma|| though not with equall gaine ||comma|| 
That resteth in the riuall of thy paine ||comma|| 
Who nere will cease to soare till he be slaine ||period|| 
neas
Dido
Tell me deare loue ||comma|| how found you out this Caue ||question_mark|| 
By chance sweete Queene ||comma|| as Mars and Venus met ||period|| 
Why ||comma|| that was in a net ||comma|| where we are loose ||comma|| 
And yet I am not free ||comma|| oh would I were ||period|| 
Why ||comma|| what is it that Dido may desire
And not obtaine ||comma|| be it in humaine power ||question_mark|| 
The thing that I will dye before I aske ||comma|| 
And yet desire to haue before I dye ||period|| 
It is not ought neas may achieue ||question_mark|| 
neas no ||comma|| although his eyes doe pearce ||period|| 
What ||comma|| hath Iarbus angred her in ought ||question_mark|| 
And will she be auenged on his life ||question_mark|| 
Not angred me ||comma|| except in angring thee ||period|| 
Who then of all so cruell may he be ||comma|| 
That should detaine thy eye in his defects ||question_mark|| 
The man that I doe eye where ere I am ||comma|| 
Whose amorous face like Pean sparkles fire ||comma|| 
When as he buts his beames on Floras bed ||comma|| 
Prometheus hath put on Cupids shape ||comma|| 
And I must perish in his burning armes:
neas ||comma|| O neas ||comma|| quench these flames ||period|| 
What ailes my Queene ||comma|| is she falne sicke of late ||question_mark|| 
Not sicke my loue ||comma|| but sicke ||comma|| I must conceale
The torment ||comma|| that it bootes me not reueale ||semicolon|| 
And yet Ile speake ||comma|| and yet Ile hold my peace ||comma|| 
Doe shame her worst ||comma|| I will disclose my griefe:
neas ||comma|| thou art he ||comma|| what did I say ||question_mark|| 
Something it was that now I haue forgot ||period|| 
What meanes faire Dido by this doubtfull speech ||question_mark|| 
Nay ||comma|| nothing ||comma|| but neas loues me not ||period|| 
neas thoughts dare not ascend so high
As heart ||comma|| which Monarkes might not scale ||period|| 
It was because I sawe no King like thee ||comma|| 
Whose golden Crowne might ballance my content:
But now that I haue found what to effect ||comma|| 
I followe one that loueth fame for me ||comma|| 
And rather had seeme faire Sirens eyes ||comma|| 
Then to the Carthage Queene that dyes for him ||period|| 
If that your maiestie can looke so lowe ||comma|| 
As my despised worths ||comma|| that shun all praise ||comma|| 
With this my hand I giue to you my heart ||comma|| 
And vow by all the Gods of Hospitalitie ||comma|| 
By heauen and earth ||comma|| and my faire brothers bowe ||comma|| 
By Paphos ||comma|| Capys ||comma|| and the purple Sea ||comma|| 
From whence my radiant mother did descend ||comma|| 
And by this Sword that saued me from the Greekes ||comma|| 
Neuer to leaue these newe vpreared walles ||comma|| 
Whiles Dido liues and rules in Iunos towne ||comma|| 
Neuer to like or loue any but her ||period|| 
What more then delian musicke doe I heare ||comma|| 
That calles my soule from forth his liuing seate ||comma|| 
To moue vnto the measures of delight:
Kind clowdes that sent forth such a curteous storme ||comma|| 
As made disdaine to flye to fancies lap:
Stoute loue in mine armes make thy Italy ||comma|| 
Whose Crowne and kingdome rests at thy commande ||period|| 
Sicheus ||comma|| not neas be thou calde:
The King of Carthage ||comma|| not Anchises sonne:
Hold ||comma|| take these Iewels at thy Louers hand ||comma|| 
These golden bracelets ||comma|| and this wedding ring ||comma|| 
Wherewith my husband woo ||single_quote|| d me yet a maide ||comma|| 
And be thou king of Libia ||comma|| by my guift ||period|| 
Did euer men see such a sudden storme ||question_mark|| 
Or day so cleere so suddenly orecast ||question_mark|| 
I thinke some fell Inchantresse dwelleth here ||comma|| 
That can call them forth when as she please ||comma|| 
And diue into blacke tempests treasurie ||comma|| 
When as she mcanes to maske the world with clowdes ||period|| 
In all my life I neuer knew the like ||comma|| 
It haild ||comma|| it snowde ||comma|| it lightned all at once ||period|| 
I thinke it was the diuels reuelling night ||comma|| 
There was such hurly burly in the heauens:
Doubtles Apollos Axeltree is crackt ||comma|| 
Or aged Atlas shoulder out of ioynt ||comma|| 
The motion was soouer violent ||period|| 
In all this coyle ||comma|| where haue ye left the Queene ||question_mark|| 
Nay ||comma|| where is my warlike father ||comma|| can you tell ||question_mark|| 
Behold where both of them come forth the Caue ||period|| 
Come forth the Caue: can heauen endure this sight ||question_mark|| 
Iarbus ||comma|| curse that vnreuenging Ioue ||comma|| 
Whose flintie darts slept in Tiphous den ||comma|| 
Whiles these adulterers surfetted with sinne:
Nature ||comma|| why mad ||single_quote|| st me not some poysonous beast ||comma|| 
That with the sharpnes of my edged sting ||comma|| 
I might haue stakte them both vnto the earth ||comma|| 
Whil ||single_quote|| st they were sporting in this darksome Caue ||question_mark|| 
The ayre is cleere ||comma|| and Southerne windes are whist ||comma|| 
Come Dido ||comma|| let vs hasten to the towne ||comma|| 
Since gloomie olus doth cease to frowne ||period|| 
Achates and Ascanius ||comma|| well met ||period|| 
Faire Anna ||comma|| how escapt you from the shower ||question_mark|| 
As others did ||comma|| by running to the wood ||period|| 
But where were you Iarbus all this while ||question_mark|| 
Not with neas in the vgly Caue ||period|| 
I see neas sticketh in your minde ||comma|| 
But I will soone put by that stumbling blocke ||comma|| 
And quell those hopes that thus employ your cares ||period|| 
Come seruants ||comma|| come bring forth the Sacrifize ||comma|| 
That I may pacifie that gloomie Ioue ||comma|| 
Whose emptie Altars haue enlarg ||single_quote|| d our illes ||period|| 
Eternall Ioue ||comma|| great master of the Clowdes ||comma|| 
Father of gladnesse ||comma|| and all frollicke thoughts ||comma|| 
That with thy gloomie hand corrects the heauen ||comma|| 
When ayrie creatures warre amongst themselues:
Heare ||comma|| heare ||comma|| O heare Iarbus plaining prayers ||comma|| 
Whose hideous ecchoes make the welkin howle ||comma|| 
And all the woods Eliza to resound:
The woman that thou wild vs entertaine ||comma|| 
Where straying in our borders vp and downe ||comma|| 
She crau ||single_quote|| d a hide of ground to build a towne ||comma|| 
With whom we did deuide both lawes and land ||comma|| 
And all the fruites that plentie els sends forth ||comma|| 
Scorning our loues and royall marriage rites ||comma|| 
Yeelds vp her beautie to a strangers bed ||comma|| 
Who hauing wrought her shame ||comma|| is straight way fled:
Now if thou beest a pitying God of power ||comma|| 
On whom ruth and compassion euer waites ||comma|| 
Redresse these wrongs ||comma|| and warne him to his ships ||comma|| 
That now afflicts me with his flattering eyes ||period|| 
How now Iarbus ||comma|| at your prayers so hard ||question_mark|| 
I Anna ||comma|| is there ought you would with me ||question_mark|| 
Nay ||comma|| no such waightie busines of import ||comma|| 
But may be slackt vntill another time:
Yet if you would partake with me the cause
Of this deuotion that detaineth you ||comma|| 
I would be thankfull for such curtesie ||period|| 
Anna ||comma|| against this Troian doe I pray ||comma|| 
Who seekes to rob me of thy Sisters loue ||comma|| 
And dive into her heart by coloured lookes ||period|| 
Alas poore King that labours so in vaine ||period|| 
For her that so delighteth in thy paine:
Be rul ||single_quote|| d by me ||comma|| and seeke some other loue ||comma|| 
Whose yeelding heart may yeeld thee more reliefe ||period|| 
Mine eye is fixt where fancie cannot start ||comma|| 
O leaue me ||comma|| leaue me to my silent thoughts ||comma|| 
That register the numbers of my ruth ||comma|| 
And I will either moue the thoughtles flint ||comma|| 
Or drop out both mine eyes in drisling teares ||comma|| 
Before my sorrowes tide haue any stint ||period|| 
I will not leaue Iarbus whom I loue ||comma|| 
In this delight of dying pensiuenes:
Away with Dido ||comma|| Anna be thy song ||comma|| 
Anna that doth admire thee more then heauen ||period|| 
I may nor will list to such loathsome chaunge ||comma|| 
That intercepts the course of my desire:
Seruants ||comma|| come fetch these emptie vessels here ||comma|| 
For I will flye from these alluring eyes ||comma|| 
That doe pursue my peace where ere it goes ||period|| 
Iarbus stay ||comma|| louing Iarbus stay ||comma|| 
For I haue honey to present thee with:
Hard hearted ||comma|| wilt not deigne to heare me speake ||comma|| 
Ile follow thee with outcryes nere the lesse ||comma|| 
And strewe thy walkes with my discheueld haire ||period|| 
Carthage ||comma|| my friendly host adue ||comma|| 
Since destinie doth call me from the shoare:
Hermes this night descending in a dreame ||comma|| 
Hath summond me to fruitfull Italy:
Ioue wils it so ||comma|| my mother wils it so:
Let my Phenissa graunt ||comma|| and then I goe:
Graunt she or no ||comma|| neas must away ||comma|| 
Whose golden fortunes clogd with courtly ease ||comma|| 
Cannot ascend to Fames immortall house ||comma|| 
Or banquet in bright honors burnisht hall ||comma|| 
Till he hath furrowed Neptunes glassie fieldes ||comma|| 
And cut a passage through his toples hilles:
Achates come forth ||comma|| Sergestus ||comma|| Illioneus ||comma|| 
Cloanthus ||comma|| haste away ||comma|| neas calles ||period|| 
What willes our Lord ||comma|| or wherefore did he call ||question_mark|| 
The dreames ||left_parentheses|| braue mates ||right_parentheses|| that did beset my bed ||comma|| 
When sleepe but newly had imbrast the night ||comma|| 
Commaunds me leaue these vnrenowmed beames ||comma|| 
Whereas Nobilitie abhors to stay ||comma|| 
And none but base neas will abide:
Abourd ||comma|| abourd ||comma|| since Fates doe bid abourd ||comma|| 
And slice the Sea with sable coloured ships ||comma|| 
On whom the nimble windes may all day waight ||comma|| 
And follow them as footemen through the deepe:
Yet Dido casts her eyes like anchors out ||comma|| 
To stay my Fleete from loosing forth the Bay:
Come backe ||comma|| come backe ||comma|| I heare her crye a farre ||comma|| 
And let me linke my bodie to my lips ||comma|| 
That tyed together by the striuing tongues ||comma|| 
We may as one saile into Italy ||period|| 
Banish that ticing dame from forth your mouth ||comma|| 
And follow your foreseeing starres in all ||semicolon|| 
This is no life for men at armes to liue ||comma|| 
Where daliance doth consume a Souldiers strength ||comma|| 
And wanton motions of alluring eyes ||comma|| 
Effeminate our mindes inur ||single_quote|| d to warre ||period|| 
Why ||comma|| let vs build a Citie of our owne ||comma|| 
And not stand lingering here for amorous lookes:
Will Dido raise old Priam forth his graue ||comma|| 
And build the towne againe the Greekes did burne ||question_mark|| 
No no ||comma|| she cares not how we sinke or swimme ||comma|| 
So she may haue neas in her armes ||period|| 
To Italy ||comma|| sweete friends to Italy ||comma|| 
We will not stay a minute longer here ||period|| 
Troians abourd ||comma|| and I will follow you ||comma|| 
I faine would goe ||comma|| yet beautie calles me backe:
To leaue her so and not once say farewell ||comma|| 
Were to transgresse against all lawes of loue:
But if I vse such ceremonious thankes ||comma|| 
As parting friends accustome on the shoare ||comma|| 
Her siluer armes will coll me round about ||comma|| 
And teares of pearle ||comma|| crye stay ||comma|| neas ||comma|| stay:
Each word she sayes will then containe a Crowne ||comma|| 
And euery speech be ended with a kisse:
I may not dure this female drudgerie ||comma|| 
To sea neas ||comma|| finde out Italy ||period|| 
O Anna ||comma|| runne vnto the water side ||comma|| 
They say neas men are going abourd ||comma|| 
It may be he will steale away with them:
Stay not to answere me ||comma|| runne Anna runne ||period|| 
O foolish Troians that would steale from hence ||comma|| 
And not let Dido vnderstand their drift:
I would haue giuen Achates store of gold ||comma|| 
And Illioneus gum and Libian spice ||comma|| 
The common souldiers rich imbrodered coates ||comma|| 
And siluer whistles to controule the windes ||comma|| 
Which Circes sent Sicheus when he liued:
Vnworthie are they of a Queenes reward:
See where they come ||comma|| how might I doe to chide ||question_mark|| 
Twas time to runne ||comma|| neas had been gone ||comma|| 
The sailes were hoysing vp ||comma|| and he abourd ||period|| 
Is this thy loue to me ||question_mark|| 
O princely Dido ||comma|| giue me leaue to speake ||comma|| 
I went to take my farewell Achates ||period|| 
How haps Achates bid me not farewell ||question_mark|| 
Because I feard your grace would keepe me here ||period|| 
To rid thee of that doubt ||comma|| abourd againe ||comma|| 
I charge thee put to sea and stay not here ||period|| 
Then let neas goe abourd with vs ||period|| 
Get you abourd ||comma|| neas meanes to stay ||period|| 
The sea is rough ||comma|| the windes blow to the shoare ||period|| 
O false neas ||comma|| now the sea is rough ||comma|| 
But when you were abourd twas calme enough ||comma|| 
Thou and Achates ment to saile away ||period|| 
Hath not the Carthage Queene mine onely sonne ||question_mark|| 
Thinkes Dido I will goe and leaue him here ||question_mark|| 
neas pardon me ||comma|| for I forgot
That yong Ascanius lay with me this night:
Loue made me iealous ||comma|| but to make amends ||comma|| 
Weare the emperiall Crowne of Libia ||comma|| 
Sway thou the Punike Scepter in my steede ||comma|| 
And punish me neas for this crime ||period|| 
This kisse shall be faire punishment ||period|| 
O how a Crowne becomes neas head ||exclamation_mark|| 
Stay here neas ||comma|| and commaund as King ||period|| 
How vaine am I to weare this Diadem ||comma|| 
And beare this golden Scepter in my hand ||question_mark|| 
A Burgonet of steele ||comma|| and not a Crowne ||comma|| 
A Sword ||comma|| and not a Scepter fits neas ||period|| 
O keepe them still ||comma|| and let me gaze my fill:
Now lookes neas like immortall Ioue ||comma|| 
O where is Ganimed to hold his cup ||comma|| 
And Mercury to flye for what he calles ||comma|| 
Ten thousand Cupids houer in the ayre ||comma|| 
And fanne it in neas louely face ||comma|| 
O that the Clowdes were here wherein thou fleest ||comma|| 
That thou and I vnseene might sport our selues:
Heauens enuious of our ioyes is waxen pale ||comma|| 
And when we whisper ||comma|| then the starres fall downe ||comma|| 
To be partakers of our honey talke ||period|| 
O Dido ||comma|| patronesse of all our liues ||comma|| 
When I leaue thee ||comma|| death be my punishment ||comma|| 
Swell raging seas ||comma|| frowne wayward destinies ||comma|| 
Blow windes ||comma|| threaten ye Rockes and sandie shelfes ||comma|| 
This is the harbour that neas seekes ||comma|| 
Lets see what tempests can anoy me now ||period|| 
Not all the world can take thee from mine armes ||comma|| 
neas may commaund as many Moores ||comma|| 
As in the Sea are little water drops:
And now to make experience of my loue ||comma|| 
Faire sister Anna leade my louer forth ||comma|| 
And seated on my Gennet ||comma|| let him ride
As husband through the punicke streetes ||comma|| 
And will my guard with Mauritanian darts ||comma|| 
To waite vpon him as their soueraigne Lord ||period|| 
What if the Citizens repine thereat ||question_mark|| 
Those that dislike what Dido giues in charge ||comma|| 
Commaund my guard to slay for their offence:
Shall vulgar pesants storme at what I doe ||question_mark|| 
The ground is mine that giues them sustenance ||comma|| 
The ayre wherein they breathe ||comma|| the water ||comma|| fire ||comma|| 
All that they haue ||comma|| their lands ||comma|| their goods ||comma|| their liues ||comma|| 
And I the Goddesse of all these ||comma|| commaund
neas ride as Carthaginian King ||period|| 
neas for his parentage deserues
As large a kingdome as is Libia ||period|| 
I ||comma|| and vnlesse the destinies be false ||comma|| 
I shall be planted in as rich a land ||period|| 
Speake of no other land ||comma|| this land is thine ||comma|| 
Dido is thine ||comma|| henceforth Ile call thee Lord:
Doe as I bid thee ||comma|| sister leade the way ||comma|| 
And from a turret Ile behold my loue ||period|| 
Then here in me shall flourish Priams race ||comma|| 
And thou and I Achates ||comma|| for reuenge ||comma|| 
For Troy ||comma|| for Priam ||comma|| for his fiftie sonnes ||comma|| 
Our kinsmens loues ||comma|| and thousand guiltles soules ||comma|| 
Will leade an hoste against the hatefull Greekes ||comma|| 
And fire proude Lacedemon ore their heads ||period|| 
Speakes not neas like a Conqueror ||question_mark|| 
O blessed tempests that did driue him in ||comma|| 
O happie sand that made him runne aground:
Henceforth you shall be our Carthage Gods:
I ||comma|| but it may be he will leaue my loue ||comma|| 
And seeke a forraine land calde Italy:
O that I had a charme to keepe the windes
Within the closure of a golden ball ||comma|| 
Or that the Tyrrhen sea were in mine armes ||comma|| 
That he might suffer shipwracke on my breast ||comma|| 
As oft as he attempts to hoyst vp saile:
I must preuent him ||comma|| wishing will not serue:
Goe ||comma|| bid my Nurse take yong Ascanius ||comma|| 
And beare him in the countrey to her house ||comma|| 
neas will not goe without his sonne:
Yet left he should ||comma|| for I am full of feare ||comma|| 
Bring me his oares ||comma|| his tackling ||comma|| and his sailes ||semicolon|| 
What if I sinke his ships ||question_mark|| O heele frowne ||period|| 
Better he frowne ||comma|| then I should dye for griefe:
I cannot see him frowne ||comma|| it may not be:
Armies of foes resolu ||single_quote|| d to winne this towne ||comma|| 
Or impious traitors vowde to haue my life ||comma|| 
Affright me not ||comma|| onely neas frowne
Is that which terrifies poore heart:
Nor bloudie speares appearing in the ayre ||comma|| 
Presage the downfall of my Emperie ||comma|| 
Nor blazing Commets threatens death ||comma|| 
It is neas frowne that ends my daies:
If he forsake me not ||comma|| I neuer dye ||comma|| 
For in his lookes I see eternitie ||comma|| 
And heele make me immortall with a kisse ||period|| 
Your Nurse is gone with yong Ascanius ||comma|| 
And heres neas tackling ||comma|| oares and sailes ||period|| 
Are these the sailes that in despight of me ||comma|| 
Packt with the windes to beare neas hence ||question_mark|| 
Ile hang ye in the chamber where I lye ||comma|| 
Driue if you can my house to Italy:
Ile set the casement open that the windes
May enter in ||comma|| and once againe conspire
Against the life of me poore Carthage Queene:
But though he goe ||comma|| he stayes in Carthage still ||comma|| 
And let rich Carthage fleete vpon the seas ||comma|| 
So I may haue neas in mine armes ||period|| 
Is this the wood that grew in Carthage plaines ||comma|| 
And would be toyling in the watrie billowes ||comma|| 
To rob their mistresse of her Troian guest ||question_mark|| 
O cursed tree ||comma|| hadst thou but wit or sense ||comma|| 
To measure how I prize neas loue ||comma|| 
Thou wouldst haue leapt from out the Sailers hands ||comma|| 
And told me that neas ment to goe:
And yet I blame thee not ||comma|| thou art but wood ||period|| 
The water which our Poets terme a Nimph ||comma|| 
Why did it suffer thee to touch her breast ||comma|| 
And shrunke not backe ||comma|| knowing my loue was there ||question_mark|| 
The water is an Element ||comma|| no Nimph ||comma|| 
Why should I blame neas for his flight ||question_mark|| 
O Dido ||comma|| blame not him ||comma|| but breake his oares ||comma|| 
These were the instruments that launcht him forth ||comma|| 
Theres not so much as this base tackling too ||comma|| 
But dares to heape vp sorrowe to my heart:
Was it not you that hoysed vp these sailes ||question_mark|| 
Why burst you not ||comma|| and they fell in the seas ||question_mark|| 
For this will Dido tye ye full of knots ||comma|| 
And sheere ye all asunder with her hands:
Now serue to chastize shipboyes for their faults ||comma|| 
Ye shall no more offend the Carthage Queene ||comma|| 
Now let him hang my fauours on his masts ||comma|| 
And see if those will serue in steed of sailes:
For tackling ||comma|| let him take the chaines of gold ||comma|| 
Which I bestowd vpon his followers:
In steed of oares ||comma|| let him vse his hands ||comma|| 
And swim to Italy ||comma|| Ile keepe these sure:
Come beare them in ||period|| 
My Lord Ascanius ||comma|| ye must goe with me ||period|| 
Whither must I goe ||question_mark|| Ile stay with my mother ||period|| 
No ||comma|| thou shalt goe with me vnto my house ||comma|| 
I haue an Orchard that hath store of plums ||comma|| 
Browne Almonds ||comma|| Seruises ||comma|| ripe Figs and Dates ||comma|| 
Dewberries ||comma|| Apples ||comma|| yellow Orenges ||comma|| 
A garden where are Bee hiues full of honey ||comma|| 
Musk-roses ||comma|| and a thousand sort of flowers ||comma|| 
And in the midst doth run a siluer streame ||comma|| 
Where thou shalt see the red gild fishes leape ||comma|| 
White Swannes ||comma|| and many louely water fowles:
Now speake Ascanius ||comma|| will ye goe or no ||question_mark|| 
Come come Ile goe ||comma|| how farre hence is your house ||question_mark|| 
But hereby child ||comma|| we shall get thither straight ||period|| 
Nurse I am wearie ||comma|| will you carrie me ||question_mark|| 
I ||comma|| so youle dwell with me and call me mother ||period|| 
So youle loue me ||comma|| I care not if I doe ||period|| 
That I might liue to see this boy a man ||comma|| 
How pretilie he laughs ||comma|| goe ye wagge ||comma|| 
Youle be a twigger when you come to age ||period|| 
Say Dido what she will I am not old ||comma|| 
Ile be no more a widowe ||comma|| I am young ||comma|| 
Ile haue a husband ||comma|| or els a louer ||period|| 
A husband and no teeth ||exclamation_mark|| 
O what meane I to haue such foolish thoughts ||exclamation_mark|| 
Foolish is loue ||comma|| a toy ||comma|| O sacred loue ||comma|| 
If there be any heauen in earth ||comma|| tis loue:
Especially in women of your yeares ||period|| 
Blush blush for shame ||comma|| why shouldst thou thinke of loue ||question_mark|| 
A graue ||comma|| and not a louer fits thy age:
A graue ||comma|| why ||question_mark|| I may liue a hundred yeares ||comma|| 
Fourescore is but a girles age ||comma|| loue is sweete:
My vaines are withered ||comma|| and my sinewes drie ||comma|| 
Why doe I thinke of loue now I should dye ||question_mark|| 
Come Nurse ||period|| 
Well ||comma|| if he come a wooing he shall speede ||comma|| 
O how vnwise was I to say him nay ||exclamation_mark|| 

Triumph my mates ||comma|| our trauels are at end ||comma|| 
Here will neas build a statelier Troy ||comma|| 
Then that which grim Atrides ouerthrew:
Carthage shall vaunt her pettie walles no more ||comma|| 
For I will grace them with a fairer frame ||comma|| 
And clad her in a Chrystall liuerie ||comma|| 
Wherein the day may euermore delight:
From golden India Ganges will I fetch ||comma|| 
Whose wealthie streames may waite vpon her towers ||comma|| 
And triple wise intrench her round about:
The Sunne from Egypt shall rich odors bring ||comma|| 
Wherewith his burning beames like labouring Bees ||comma|| 
That loade their thighes with Hyblas honeys spoyles ||comma|| 
Shall here vnburden their exhaled sweetes ||comma|| 
And plant our pleasant suburbes with her fumes ||period|| 
What length or bredth shal this braue towne ctaine ||question_mark|| 
Not past foure thousand paces at the most ||period|| 
But what shall it be calde ||comma|| Troy as before ||question_mark|| 
That haue I not determinde with my selfe ||period|| 
Let it be term ||single_quote|| d nea by your name ||period|| 
Rather Ascania by your little sonne ||period|| 
Nay ||comma|| I will haue it calde Anchisaon ||comma|| 
Of my old fathers name ||period|| 
neas stay ||comma|| Ioues Herald bids thee stay ||period|| 
Whom doe I see ||comma|| Ioues winged messenger ||question_mark|| 
Welcome to Carthage new erected towne ||period|| 
Why cosin ||comma|| stand you building Cities here ||comma|| 
And beautifying the Empire of this Queene ||comma|| 
While Italy is cleane out of thy minde ||question_mark|| 
To too forgetfull of thine owne affayres ||comma|| 
Why wilt thou so betray thy sonnes good hap ||question_mark|| 
The king of Gods sent me from highest heauen ||comma|| 
To sound this angrie message in thine eares ||period|| 
Vaine man ||comma|| what Monarky expectst thou here ||question_mark|| 
Or with what thought sleepst thou in Libia shoare ||question_mark|| 
If that all glorie hath forsaken thee ||comma|| 
And thou despise the praise of such attempts:
Yet thinke vpon Ascanius prophesie ||comma|| 
And yong Iulus more then thousand yeares ||comma|| 
Whom I haue brought from Ida where he slept ||comma|| 
And bore yong Cupid vnto Cypresse Ile ||period|| 
This was my mother that beguild the Queene ||comma|| 
And made me take my brother for my sonne:
No maruell Dido though thou be in loue ||comma|| 
That daylie danlest Cupid in thy armes:
Welcome sweet child ||comma|| where hast thou been this long ||question_mark|| 
Eating sweet Comfites with Queene maide ||comma|| 
Who euer since hath luld me in her armes ||period|| 
Sergestus ||comma|| beare him hence vnto our ships ||comma||
