Lest Dido spying him keepe him for a pledge ||period|| 
Spendst thou thy time about this little boy ||comma|| 
And giuest not care vnto the charge I bring ||question_mark|| 
I tell thee thou must straight to Italy ||comma|| 
Or els abide the wrath of frowning Ioue ||period|| 
How should I put into the raging deepe ||comma|| 
Who haue no sailes nor tackling for my ships ||question_mark|| 
What would the Gods haue me Deucalion like ||comma|| 
Flote vp and downe where ere the billowes driue ||question_mark|| 
Though she repairde my fleete and gaue me ships ||comma|| 
Yet hath she tane away my oares and masts ||comma|| 
And left me neither saile nor sterne abourd ||period|| 
How now neas ||comma|| sad ||comma|| what meanes these dumpes ||question_mark|| 
Iarbus ||comma|| I am cleane besides my selfe ||comma|| 
Ioue hath heapt on me such a desperate charge ||comma|| 
Which neither art nor reason may atchieue ||comma|| 
Nor I deuise by what meanes to contriue ||period|| 
As how I pray ||comma|| may I entreat you tell ||period|| 
With speede he bids me sail to Italy ||period|| 
When as I want both rigging for my fleete ||comma|| 
And also furniture for these my men ||period|| 
If that be all ||comma|| then cheare thy drooping lookes ||comma|| 
For I will furnish thee with such supplies:
Let some of those thy followers goe with me ||comma|| 
And they shall haue what thing so ere thou needst ||period|| 
Thankes good Iarbus for thy friendly ayde ||comma|| 
Achates and the rest shall waite on thee ||comma|| 
Whil ||single_quote|| st I rest thankfull for this curtesie ||period|| 
Now will I haste vnto Lauinian shoare ||comma|| 
And raise a new foundation to old Troy ||comma|| 
Witnes the Gods ||comma|| and witnes heauen and earth ||comma|| 
How loth I am to leaue these Libian bounds ||comma|| 
But that eternall Iupiter commands ||period|| 
I feare I sawe neas little sonne ||comma|| 
Led by Achates to the Troian fleete:
If it be so ||comma|| his father meanes to flye:
But here he is ||comma|| now Dido trie thy wit ||period|| 
neas ||comma|| wherefore goe thy men abourd ||question_mark|| ||comma|| 
Why are thy ships new rigd ||question_mark|| or to what end
Launcht from the hauen ||comma|| lye they in the Rhode ||question_mark|| 
Pardon me though I aske ||comma|| loue makes me aske ||period|| 
O pardon me ||comma|| if I resolue thee why:
neas will not faine with his deare loue ||comma|| 
I must from hence: this day swift Mercury
When I was laying a platforme for these walles ||comma|| 
Sent from his father Ioue ||comma|| appeard to me ||comma|| 
And in his name rebukt me bitterly ||comma|| 
For lingering here ||comma|| neglecting Italy ||period|| 
But yet neas will not leaue his loue ||period|| 
I am commaunded by immortal Ioue ||comma|| 
To leaue this towne and passe to Italy ||comma|| 
And therefore must of force ||period|| 
These words proceed not from neas heart ||period|| 
Not from my heart ||comma|| for I can hardly goe ||comma|| 
And yet I may not stay ||comma|| Dido farewell ||period|| 
Farewell: is this the mends for loue ||question_mark|| 
Doe Troians vse to quit their Louers thus ||question_mark|| 
Fare well may Dido ||comma|| so neas stay ||comma|| 
I dye ||comma|| if my neas say farewell ||period|| 
Then let me goe and neuer say farewell ||comma|| 
Let me goe ||comma|| farewell ||comma|| I must from hence ||period|| 
These words are poyson to poore soule ||comma|| 
O speake like my neas ||comma|| like my loue:
Why look ||single_quote|| st thou toward the sea ||question_mark|| the time hath been
When beautie chaungd thine eyes to her ||semicolon|| 
Am I lesse faire then when thou sawest me first ||question_mark|| 
O then neas ||comma|| tis for griefe of thee:
Say thou wilt stay in Carthage with my Queene ||comma|| 
And beautie will returne againe:
neas ||comma|| say ||comma|| how canst thou take thy leaue ||question_mark|| 
Wilt thou kisse Dido ||question_mark|| O thy lips haue sworne
To stay with Dido: canst thou take her hand ||question_mark|| 
Thy Hand and mine haue plighted mutuall faith ||comma|| 
Therefore vnkinde neas ||comma|| must thou say ||comma|| 
Then let me goe ||comma|| and neuer say farewell ||period|| 
O Queene of Carthage ||comma|| wert thou vgly blacke ||comma|| 
neas could not choose but hold thee deare ||comma|| 
Yet must he not gainsay the Gods behest ||period|| 
The Gods ||comma|| what Gods be those that seeke my death ||question_mark|| 
Wherein haue I offended Iupiter ||comma|| 
That he should take neas from mine armes ||question_mark|| 
O no ||comma|| the Gods wey not what Louers doe ||comma|| 
It is neas calles neas hence ||comma|| 
And wofull Dido by these blubbred cheekes ||comma|| 
By this right hand ||comma|| and by our spousall rites ||comma|| 
Si bene quid de te merui ||comma|| fuit aut tibi quidquam
Dulce meum ||comma|| miserere domus labentis: & istam
Oro ||comma|| si quis ad hac precibus locus ||comma|| exue mentem ||period|| 
Desine meque tuis incendere teque querelis ||comma|| 
Italiam non sponte sequor ||period|| 
Hast thou forgot how many neighbour kings
Were vp in armes ||comma|| for making thee my loue ||question_mark|| 
How Carthage did rebell ||comma|| Iarbus storme ||comma|| 
And all the world calles me a second Helen ||comma|| 
For being intangled by a strangers lookes:
So thou wouldst proue as true as Paris did ||comma|| 
Would ||comma|| as faire Troy was ||comma|| Carthage might be sackt ||comma|| 
And I be calde a second Helena ||period|| 
Had I a sonne by thee ||comma|| the griefe were lesse ||comma|| 
That I might see neas in his face:
Now if thou goest ||comma|| what canst thou leaue behind ||comma|| 
But rather will augment then ease my woe ||question_mark|| 
In vaine my loue thou spendst thy fainting breath ||comma|| 
If words might moue me I were ouercome ||period|| 
And wilt thou not be mou ||single_quote|| d with words ||question_mark|| 
Thy mother was no Goddesse periurd man ||comma|| 
Nor Dardanus the author of thy stocke:
But thou art Sprung from Scythian Caucasus ||comma|| 
And Tygers of Hircania gaue thee sucke:
Ah foolish Dido to forbeare this long ||exclamation_mark|| 
Wast thou not wrackt vpon this Libian shoare ||comma|| 
And cam ||single_quote|| st to Dido like a Fisherswaine ||question_mark|| 
Repairde not I thy ships ||comma|| made thee a King ||comma|| 
And all thy needie followers Noblemen ||question_mark|| 
O Serpent that came creeping from the shoare ||comma|| 
And I for pitie harbord in my bosome ||comma|| 
Wilt thou now slay me with thy venomed sting ||comma|| 
And hisse at Dido for preseruing thee ||question_mark|| 
Goe goe and spare not ||comma|| seeke out Italy ||comma|| 
I hope that that which loue forbids me doe ||comma|| 
The Rockes and Sea-gulfes will performe at large ||comma|| 
And thou shalt perish in the billowes waies ||comma|| 
To whom poore Dido doth bequeath reuenge ||comma|| 
I traytor ||comma|| and the waues shall cast thee vp ||comma|| 
Where thou and false Achates first set foote:
Which if it chaunce ||comma|| Ile giue ye buriall ||comma|| 
And weepe vpon your liueles carcases ||comma|| 
Though thou nor he will pitie me a whit ||period|| 
Why star ||single_quote|| st thou in my face ||question_mark|| if thou wilt stay ||comma|| 
Leape in mine armes ||comma|| mine armes are open wide:
If not ||comma|| turne from me ||comma|| and Ile turne from thee ||semicolon|| 
For though thou hast the heart to say farewell ||comma|| 
I haue not power to stay thee: is he gone ||question_mark|| 
I but heele come againe ||comma|| he cannot goe ||comma|| 
He loues me to too well to serue me so:
Yet he that in my sight would not relent ||comma|| 
Will ||comma|| being absent ||comma|| be abdurate still ||period|| 
By this is he got to the water side ||comma|| 
And ||comma|| see the Sailers take him by the hand ||comma|| 
But he shrinkes backe ||comma|| and now remembring me ||comma|| 
Returnes amaine: welcome ||comma|| welcome my loue:
But wheres neas ||question_mark|| ah hees gone hees gone ||exclamation_mark|| 
What meanes my sister thus to raue and crye ||question_mark|| 
O Anna ||comma|| my neas is abourd ||comma|| 
And leauing me will saile to Italy ||period|| 
Once didst thou goe ||comma|| and he came backe againe ||comma|| 
Now bring him backe ||comma|| and thou shalt be a Queene ||comma|| 
And I will liue a priuate life with him ||period|| 
Wicked neas ||period|| 
Call him not wicked ||comma|| sister speake him faire ||comma|| 
And looke vpon him with a Mermaides eye ||comma|| 
Tell him ||comma|| I neuer vow ||single_quote|| d at Aulis gulfe
The desolation of his natiue Troy ||comma|| 
Nor sent a thousand ships vnto the walles ||comma|| 
Nor euer violated faith to him:
Request him gently ||left_parentheses|| Anna ||right_parentheses|| to returne ||comma|| 
I craue but this ||comma|| he stay a tide or two ||comma|| 
That I may learne to beare it patiently ||comma|| 
If he depart thus suddenly ||comma|| I dye:
Run Anna ||comma|| run ||comma|| stay not to answere me ||period|| 
I goe faire sister ||comma|| heauens graunt good successe ||period|| 
O Dido ||comma|| your little sonne Ascanius
Is gone ||exclamation_mark|| he lay with me last night ||comma|| 
And in the morning he was stolne from me ||comma|| 
I thinke some Fairies haue beguiled me ||period|| 
O cursed hagge and false dissembling wretch ||exclamation_mark|| 
That slayest me with thy harsh and hellish tale ||comma|| 
Thou for some pettie guift hast let him goe ||comma|| 
And I am thus deluded of my boy:
Away with her to prison presently ||comma|| 
Traytoresse too keend and cursed Sorceresse ||period|| 
I know not what you meane by treason ||comma|| I ||comma|| 
I am as true as any one of yours ||period|| 
Away with her ||comma|| suffer her not to speake ||period|| 
My sister comes ||comma|| I like not her sad lookes ||period|| 
Before I came ||comma|| neas was abourd ||comma|| 
And spying me ||comma|| hoyst vp the sailes amaine:
But I cride out ||comma|| neas ||comma|| false neas stay ||period|| 
Then gan he wagge his hand ||comma|| which yet held vp ||comma|| 
Made me suppose he would haue heard me speake:
Then gan they driue into the Ocean ||comma|| 
Which when I viewd ||comma|| I cride ||comma|| neas stay ||comma|| 
Dido ||comma|| faire Dido wils neas stay:
Yet he whose heart of adamant or flint ||comma|| 
My teares nor plaints could mollifie a whit:
Then carelesly I rent my haire for griefe ||comma|| 
Which seene to all ||comma|| though he beheld me not ||comma|| 
They gan to moue him to redresse my ruth ||comma|| 
And stay a while to heare what I could say ||comma|| 
But he clapt vnder hatches saild away ||period|| 
O Anna ||comma|| Anna ||comma|| I will follow him ||period|| 
How can ye goe when he hath all your fleete ||question_mark|| 
Ile frame me wings of waxe like Icarus ||comma|| 
And ore his ships will soare vnto the Sunne ||comma|| 
That they may melt and I fall in his armes:
Or els Ile make a prayer vnto the waues ||comma|| 
That I may swim to him like Tritons neece:
O Anna ||comma|| fetch Orions Harpe ||comma|| 
That I may tice a Dolphin to the shoare ||comma|| 
And ride vpon his backe vnto my loue:
Looke sister ||comma|| looke louely neas ships ||comma|| 
See see ||comma|| the billowes heaue him vp to heauen ||comma|| 
And now downe falles the keeles into the deepe:
O sister ||comma|| sister ||comma|| take away the Rockes ||comma|| 
Theile breake his ships ||comma|| O Proteus ||comma|| Neptune ||comma|| Ioue ||comma|| 
Saue ||comma|| saue neas ||comma|| leefest loue ||exclamation_mark|| 
Now is he come on shoare safe without hurt:
But see ||comma|| Achates wils him put to sea ||comma|| 
And all the Sailers merrie make for ioy ||comma|| 
But he remembring me shrinkes backe againe:
See where he comes ||comma|| welcome ||comma|| welcome my loue ||period|| 
Ah sister ||comma|| leaue these idle fantasies ||comma|| 
Sweet sister cease ||comma|| remember who you are ||period|| 
FEMALE 
I am ||comma|| vnlesse I be deceiu ||single_quote|| d ||comma|| 
And must I raue thus for a renegate ||question_mark|| 
Must I make ships for him to saile away ||question_mark|| 
Nothing can beare me to him but a ship ||comma|| 
And he hath all thy fleete ||comma|| what shall I doe ||question_mark|| 
But dye in furie of this ouersight ||question_mark|| 
I ||comma|| I must be the murderer of my selfe:
No but I am not ||comma|| yet I will be straight ||period|| 
Anna be glad ||comma|| now haue I found a meane
To rid me from these thoughts of Lunacie:
Not farre from hence there is a woman famoused for arts ||comma|| 
Daughter vnto the Nimphs Hesperides ||comma|| 
Who wild me sacrifice his ticing relliques:
Goe Anna ||comma|| bid my seruants bring me fire ||period|| 
How long will Dido mourne a strangers flight ||comma|| 
That hath dishonord her and Carthage both ||question_mark|| 
How long shall I with griefe consume my daies ||comma|| 
And reape no guerdon for my truest loue ||question_mark|| 
Iarbus ||comma|| talk not of neas ||comma|| let him goe ||comma|| 
Lay to thy hands and helpe me make a fire ||comma|| 
That shall consume all that this stranger left ||comma|| 
For I entend a priuate Sacrifize ||comma|| 
To cure my minde that melts for vnkind loue ||period|| 
But afterwards will Dido graunt me loue ||question_mark|| 
I ||comma|| I ||comma|| Iarbus ||comma|| after this is done ||comma|| 
None in the world shall have my loue but thou:
So ||comma|| leaue me now ||comma|| let none approach this place ||period|| 
Now Dido ||comma|| with these reliques burne thy selfe ||comma|| 
And make neas famous through the world ||comma|| 
For periurie and slaughter of a Queene:
Here lye the Sword that in the darksome Caue
He drew ||comma|| and swore by to be true to me ||comma|| 
Thou shalt burne first ||comma|| thy crime is worse then his:
Here lye the garment which I cloath ||single_quote|| d him in ||comma|| 
When first he came on shoare ||comma|| perish thou to:
These letters ||comma|| lines ||comma|| and periurd papers all ||comma|| 
Shall burne to cinders in this prectious flame ||period|| 
And now ye Gods that guide the starrie frame ||comma|| 
And order all things at your high dispose ||semicolon|| 
Graunt ||comma|| though the traytors land in Italy ||comma|| 
They may be still tormented with vnrest ||comma|| 
And from mine ashes let a Conquerour rise ||comma|| 
That may reuenge this treason to a Queene ||comma|| 
By plowing vp his Countries with the Sword:
Betwixt this land and that be neuer league ||comma|| 
Littora littoribus contraria ||comma|| fluctibus undas
Impresor: arma armis: pugnent ipsig nepotes:
Liue false neas ||comma|| truest Dido dyes ||comma|| 
Sic sic inuat ire sub umbras ||period|| 
O helpe Iarbus ||comma|| Dido in these flames
Hath burnt her selfe ||comma|| aye me ||comma|| vnhappie me ||exclamation_mark|| 
Cursed Iarbus ||comma|| dye to expiate
The griefe that tires vpon thine inward soule ||comma|| 
Dido I come to thee ||comma|| aye me neas ||period|| 
What can my teares or cryes preuaile me now ||question_mark|| 
Dido is dead ||comma|| Iarbus slaine ||comma|| Iarbus my deare loue ||comma|| 
O sweet Iarbus ||comma|| sole delight ||comma|| 
What fatall destinie enuies me thus ||comma|| 
To see my sweet Iarbus slay himselfe ||question_mark|| 
But Anna now shall honor thee in death ||comma|| 
And mixe her bloud with thine ||comma|| this shall I doe ||comma|| 
That Gods and men may pitie this my death ||comma|| 
And rue our ends senceles of life or breath ||semicolon|| 
Now sweet Iarbus stay ||comma|| I come to thee ||period||
